reviewText:
There is a sprinkling of redeeming features found in this game. It has a neat cyberpunk atmosphere. You can hack into an enemy soldier's mind and force him to shoot his comrades. You can block bullets with a sword like you're in some cheesy action movie. You can augment features of your cybernetic implants a la Deus Ex to run faster, hit harder, resist damage, et cetera. The rest of the game is a pile of garbage.

The game is terribly short, and tries to make up for it by requiring multiple playthroughs. The single player story consists of five or so missions that don't take long to complete. You fight the final boss after a few hours and the game ends. On your first run through, the story is largely incomprehensible and completely nonsensical and only adds to the confusion you feel when the campaign abruptly finishes. The campaign is so short that there's no time to specialize your character, and even having enough money and experience to really explore the roleplaying elements of the game requires running through the game a few times. Sadly, it's very possible to beat the game without upgrading your character at all.

You don't need to buy augmentations and abilities for your character to customize him, though: you can choose what kind of armor you want to wear (heavy, medium, or light) and manage a grid-based (again, think Deus Ex) inventory. This kind of freedom would be welcome and greatly improve the game--if there were any point to it. The balance in viability between different styles of play and equipment is terrible: trying to play a stealthy, melee-heavy character is extremely challenging, while wearing heavy armor, lugging around a minigun, and swiss cheesing everything in sight is essentially putting the game on easy mode.

There are side missions that you can play to prolong a playthrough, but they kind of suck. There are two kinds: laughably easy and absurdly hard. They're over in minutes either way and there are so few of them that they barely serve to add content.

If this game had actual, fleshed-out roleplaying and multiple ways to approach combat and a story mode that couldn't be finished in a single afternoon then I would recommend it. But it doesn't. Hell, there are other glaring, game-breaking flaws I didn't even bother to explain in this review. Avoid this poorly made game.

Game turned me off at first with its unintuitive UI, mechanics, and strange setting, but once I got used to all that the game became immensely satisfying. Gunplay is actaully really solid and the story while weird is intriguing when you figure it out. Loved the deep RPG mechanics and the multiple paths you could take throughout the campaign and the game highly encourages replayability and trying things out differently which is great. Very fun to be a badass cyborg/knight/psychic/ninja.

Liked this game a whole lot. Highly recommend it to anybody that loves FPS/RPGs that gives you lots of freedom to play however you want. It's like a surreal French Deus Ex mixed with Warhammer 40k mixed with Jacob's Ladder (the movie).

This game also gets huge bonus points for having the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ CYBERDEMON FROM DOOM as an enemy type!

reviewText:
This is a great game but I only recommend it if you don't mind reading in depth, complicated storylines with zero context from our known world. In other words, you'll probably be lost with the story for a while but you'll get a lot more enjoyment from it if you understand what is going on.

Pros:
originality
gritty feel
cool cybernetics and psych abilities
decent story line with alternate endings
immersion

Cons:
-written by people whose first language is not English, so there are grammatical mistakes and unnatural phrasing (this wasn't a big issue for me and I didn't feel like it pulled me out of the story while I was trying to figure out what they were saying but I see that a lot of people complain about it)
-confusing, almost disappointing, ending at first (but finish the game and then google alternate endings)
-something like 24 tutorial videos that put me off from playing for a while
-the A.I. is very 'meh' and it shows its age

I wish there was a button between recommending this game and not recommending it. I would not recommend this game to most people because I don't think they would have an appreciation for it and it definitely has its flaws. However, I bought this game because it gave me a certain feeling when I watched the gameplay videos and I was not disappointed.

reviewText:
This is one of those cases where you will either hate it, or love it. Or, more likely, hate it, then love it.
This game is an embodiment of confusion. While the mechanics themselves are not that complex and opaque, the way they are presented makes understanding them quite a hard task. But once you get a hang of them, you suddenly begin to have loads of fun.
The gunplay is solid, and every weapon feels actually useful, although some are clearly outclassed by others (I'm looking at you, Rotten Mound). Apart from Betty Boom, shotguns here avert the classic disease of extreme spread and low range. Assault rifles all have a semi-auto mode, which immensely helps at long range. Then there is a pistol that can shoot through walls and disregard any armor you target might be clad in, an automatic sticky proximity grenade launcher, minigun (which is REALLY awesome), thermonuclear cannon with 10m blast radius and an ancient warhammer capable of killing almost any enemy in the game in one hit.
Art direction is kinda all over the place stylistically, with classic cyberpunk tropes like implants, megacorps, oppressive government and violent anarchists in the slums coexisting with 40K-esque high fantasy stuff like psionics, the eponymous E.Y.E, metastreumonic force, ancient civilizations and necromancy. But in the end it feels vary wholesome and high in quality.
The story is something you have to experience on your own. It's very confusing until almost the very end, where you get the general idea of what's going on.
Cybernetic implants and psionics are VERY cool and VERY fun to use. Upgrade you cyberlegs and you'll be able to outrun a cheetah and jump a dozen meters high. Get the Dragon's Breath psi power and you'll be able to literally telefrag your enemies. Makes for a handy quick way to move across the levels, too.
Speaking of levels, they are vast and sprawling, full of little nooks and corners with extreme amount of detail everywhere. Although their size can make them somewhat tedious to traverse early on.
Difficulty is completely customizable with half a dozen of default presets and a plenty of options which can be fine-tuned individually to suit your preferences the best.

reviewText:
E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is unlike anything you will ever play. Despite my relatively short playtime, it's one of the most memorable games I've played in a long, long time.

E.Y.E. has fantastic world design, extreme depth in its mechanics, and extremely well done core game mechanics, but it's also user-unfriendly, unpolished, and some of the text appears to be some sort of almost-English language. It has more quality content than most games on the market, even full-priced $60 games, but for nearly every good piece of content in the game, there's some factor that just makes you scratch your head.

Both as a shooter and as an RPG, E.Y.E. have a very well-designed core. It allows you to build any kind of character, from a high-tech, heavily augmented super-hacker to a nimble assassin, a cloaked sniper to a heavily-armored living tank, from a berserker wielding explosive katanas to a psychokinetic mage who can telefrag people at will while your clones distract enemies. And each of these builds, and all the builds in-between, can be tuned and tweaked to your liking.

There are no class limitations or restrictions, so long as you can plan your stats for what you want to use. These classes are defined by your stats you gain by leveling up, your research you commit to with items you find in the field, and your cybernetic augments that you graft onto yourself as you progress through the game.

However, despite the fundamentals of this system being brilliantly done, in practice, there are some builds which are far less practical than others. While being a mind-hacker or psionic mastermind may be very appealing, they are ultimately far less practical than a simple soldier with good guns, or a melee fighter with enough accuracy for an anti-armor handcannon. Fortunately, playing E.Y.E. as purely a shooter, with no bells and whistles attached, is still a great time, but this may disappoint players that were hoping to jump into a first run with one of these builds.

More straightforward builds will lead to a better experience for two reasons: difficulty of use, and utter non-information on the complex mechanics of certain builds. The difficulty comes from some builds giving you limited to no ability to directly fight enemies, leaving you with a lack of XP sources to improve yourself further. This is particularly egregious with hacking, as hacking an enemy takes longer, is less effective, and grants lower XP, and gives less money than just shooting the enemy in the first place would. And the greatest shame here is that almost every build in E.Y.E. is an absolute blast to play; it's a ton of fun. Some builds just don't give you the resources you need to reasonably progress like others do.

The other problem with certain builds is that they aren't well explained. The first sign of this problem comes in the form of a tutorial system that's better off ignored with how poorly implemented it is. The in-game tutorial shows you how to run, jump, crawl, climb ladders, etc., all things you should already know. But the fine details are left to videos in a menu. The predominant limitation, however, comes from extremely vague descriptions of items and abilities, leaving you to occasionally guess at what things do. When fundamental, build-defining skills can't be identified without being told, there's a serious problem. Fortunately, many of these issues are front-loaded, and after a couple of hours, explanation issues taper down to a tolerable level.

Speaking of incomprehensible content, the Research in this game is more of a crapshoot than anything if you don't look up a guide. Without researching it ahead of time, I couldn't tell you what my reward was for researching UbiCosif Substance"
date: or "Alpha Bio Optical Connex". According to tech trees
recommended:
some of the research actually does nothing.

================================

So far

reviewText:
I strongly recommend this game if you want to play a unique game which offers you (IF you manage to get into it) an fantastic gameplay with tons of fun.

PROS:
- good story with 3 different endings
- tons of sidemissions (All randomized)
- huge maps
- modable (But no Workshop)
- Source engine
- SPLATTER!
- unique gameplay which offers you to play the way you want
- many psi powers
- possibility to jump around the map and kill everyone like a ninja on drugs
- really fun with friends
- realistic injuries and causes of death (e.g. drugoverdose because of too much healing)
- there is ALWAYS a server to play
- NO DLC's (!)
- COOP and PvP
- different enemy ranks (e.g. Captains, Seargents, etc.)
- different enemy types
- ...

CONS
- graphics not the best for todays expactations
- hard to get into (but with the T-key most problems will get solved (it opens ingame videos in the game))
- sometimes the game is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (because it is so hard, well which is also a PRO I think?)
- there aren't many players around to play with

Well thats it. I recommend it to buy it when it is on a sale for 1 or 2 bucks so you dont make a mistake if you dont like it (Though 10 bucks aren't much).
89/100

reviewText:
This is the best bad game I'd ever play! This abomination, is well worth your time and the money it costs to buy.
Basically, you're an amnesiac killer power-armored psychic bioenhanced cyborg member of a secret fraternity of warrior-monks which is fighting the legitimate government. Truth be told, I barely understand it, but that's not the reason I like it.

It includes rpg elements and character upgrades, including cybernetic upgrades, leveling up, buying superpowers...
Many ways to play; if you want to play the game as a stealthy hacker ninja, you can. If you want to put on heavy armor, grab the (stupidly overpowered) minigun, and pretend you're the Terminator and walk through a dozen rockets and about a thousand bullets, you can too. If you want to summon hordes of clones and unleash them on your foes, you can do that too. Did I mention you can hack enemies into this game and possess or MIND CONTROL them? Well... you can.
If you get bored of guns, you can use melee weapons. And this isn't just a joke, the melee weapons in this game are death machines. You have swords that cause people to literally explode. And you can parry bullets with them like a jedi!

Also, the game's designers and writers are all French, so there is that amazingly hilarious bad translation. Nothing in this game makes sense, but it's a good kind of insane.

And, of course, it has that superb full coop gameplay, really fun.

reviewText:
It's been a while since I last reviewed a game on Steam - or anywhere else for that matter - and to break this trend I decided to write up some of my experiences with the things I've been playing. As a bonus, I will try to make use of the text formatting that has been introduced by Steam in the meantime.

IntroductionFirst up on that list is E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy (abbreviated as EYE from here on), an FPS/RPG crossover made by the relatively unknown ‘Streumon Studio’, which should sound familiar if you have played the Half Life 1 total conversion mod called ‘Syndicate Black Ops’. On a sidenote here: people have been notifying me that some of the games I write about are rather old and as such my efforts might not be read by anyone. I’m fully aware of this and it is no problem to me. Some games stand the passing of time well and others even manage to become more appealing as they age, a phenomena caused by nostalgia and the fact that this industry is being saturated by bad titles.

MeritI would consider EYE one of the latter category. While it is certainly not ugly, I wouldn’t dare call it a beautiful game either. A disadvantage with realism as far as graphics are concerned is that they do not measure up to titles that release later on. Of course that’s an unfair comparison, but it’s one that will be made regardless. Games like World of Warcraft that go for the full comic book style graphics can sport ‘kiddy’ visuals for years to come, but has it done their setting any justice? Only a fanboy would concur. Instead, realistic graphics has to come with dramatization in order to increase the shelf like for the demanding gamer. The most obvious examples would be the brilliant bloom effects in Lineage 2’s Angel Waterfall, the gold shaders in Deus Ex: Human Revolution, or the blend of drawings with old graphics used in the Mount & Blade series. While EYE has constituted their theme pretty well, the use of some low resolution textures and models here and there can still break the immersion. That aside, it’s a very good effort that is very commendable, especially during the dream and certain parts of the HQ. In fact, in some parts it's quite extreme, think of huge power cables running through the streets and even fighting on Mars.

The strength of EYE definitely appears to be the character customization but the sounds and shooting mechanics are actually more fleshed out. At first this might seem like an odd thing to say as there are many powers and augmentations to choose from, however, as you progress through the levels you will come to find that specializing your character in a specific playstyle does not pay off. With the current state of the variables it is much more viable to build a generic tank/gunner as  the other powers are either too taxing or influence your character too little to make much of a difference in battle. My character is currently level 40+ and having failed to be a drone master – since every enemy in the game gets tougher and my drones only gained a one time marginal HP increase and cannot be replenished during firefights – I noticed that straightforward upgrades related to gun performance and health will give you better results. It’s rather sad, but I understand that these niche playstyles are uncommon so they are represented less.

Last, but not leastIf you read my reviews before you will probably be wondering why I haven’t mentioned anything about the storyline yet, the reason for that is that I can’t. The storyline isn’t bad, just very complicated! I will really need to finish a couple more playthroughs to really get the gist of it.

In conclusionAll in all, E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy is a well designed game assuming a setting that is underrepresented in comparison to other themes. If you enjoy cyberpunk then you have probably come at the right address, though keep in mind that the theme is anything but subtle and the customization could be better.

reviewText:
The game is a horrible mess of a weird ♥♥♥ plot, odd translations, weird mechanics, lack of any real direction initially, and a horrible unuser friendly way of getting any multiplayer games going.

The game is a joyous empowering romp through hundreds of enemies warhammer style, with tight first person shooter/hack n slash gameplay, with gorgeous cyberpunk graphics, and a philosophical tale that will make even the most studied scholar scratch his head, and rpg elements that feeling meaningful and non hindering to the gameplay.

Expect to be lost, confused, amazed, frustrated, unstoppable and hopeless. When you finnaly understand what the game is you will become addicted to the lore and gameplay in such a way you may never feel like you will understand it all but at the same time feel like you uncovered some weird secret to life.

Buy it if you are open minded, not expecting fallout/deus ex, and don't need closure.

reviewText:
Imagine playing a lot of Deus Ex and S.T.A.L.K.E.R, ingesting illicit substances, knocking yourself out, and living in a terrifying dreamland for the next 24 hours. That dream would be E.Y.E: The Divine Cybermancy.

You play as a psychic cyborg space marine who has the power to jump several stories in the air, turn invisible, hack computers, clone himself instantly, and much more. If you want, you can sneak around levels stealthily and backstab enemies, or you can put on heavy armor and blow everything up with a minigun. Enemies still overpowering you? Use your psychic powers to drive them insane with hallucinations. If none of those work, you can remotely hack any computer on the level, including the cyborg brains of humans, and then mind control everyone. Once you hack someone's brain, you can see the world through their vision and give them commands. They'll struggle against your control, but if you keep mashing the attack" button then sooner or later they'll kill all of their friends for you.

Be careful
date: because any of these techniques can be used against you too. Invisible assassins can snipe you. Psychic monsters can empty your sanity meter

The truth may or may not be revealed in the end.\n\nI haven't even mentioned a lot of the other surreal aspects of it. Up to 32 people can play together in the campaign at once. About half of your dialog options will tell characters to ♥♥♥♥ themselves. Occasionally

reviewText:
I'll recommend this game, but only if you can get it on a sale of some sort.

While the game is a little bit glitchy in terms of saving from time to time, most of the time it holds up really well. After validating, I've only had it crash once. Translations aren't perfect, and some of the words are just really hard to pronounce, much less know how to spell off hand. Though, this isn't really obstructive to gameplay, given you can easily figure things out if you think for a few moments.

The game won't tell you all the default keys, you're going to want to check those, as the tutorial isn't going to answer that for you either. The tutorials frankly aren't that beneficial, they'll give you the very basic, but fully employing something is going to take trial and error.

Actual gameplay wise... The game is great really, you're not restricted to just being the heavy armored titan who shambles along mowing down everything he sees. Sure, in the beginning you're going to be more or less locked into the basic strategies of, long range versus close range... But very soon, you'll be able to make yourself capable of stealth, tanking, hacking, and more.

To explain what I mean to those thinking of buying this game:
The game does have a stealth system. It's normally impossible to be stealthy unless you use the cloak implant that you can buy pretty early in. If you hit someone who hasn't detected you, you will get a pretty nicely sized modifier to your hit.
Hacking; is actually a very powerful tool in the game if you can get a few good strategies for it going. You can quite literally make your enemies turn against each other, ignore, and even defend you. You can take a glance through someone's eyes... Or you can flat out cause brain death by hacking a person. However, hacking isn't possible on all enemies in the game.
There's varieties of every type of gun in the game, each with a unique aspect. Just looking at melee, the Distortion Hammer is big, heavy, slow... But it causes massive damage, and it can work great as a shield (yes, you can block using weapons, bigger weapons are better at blocking). There's also the dual blades, which are fast, lethal, but lack the damage per hit and blocking power of the hammer. In short; you can play it light, quiet and quick... Or big, heavy, and monsterous... With any weapon really.

Your special" stuff doesn't come from killstreaks or anything like that

reviewText: Honestly, I don't know what to feel about this game. There's great ideas, but it's plagued by poor execution(stealth is a joke until you jump through the million hoops needed to get the Cloak, which does more than conceal your visual presence apparently) and occasionally overwhelming info dumps that just make you wonder if you're reading a book pretending to be a game. It's a genuinely good shooter when it wants to be, but the grind gets horrid. I feel like the devs have potential, and could make something great if they tweaked this formula.\n\nI will admit that this game's story is amazing though. Gotta hand it to the devs, because it's been like 2 or 3 years and we still haven't discovered the ultimate ending.

reviewText:
While it may say 42 hours on record, my actual record in E.Y.E is 84. So I think I have enough experience with this game to finally review it.

First off, I'm just going to warn future buyers that E.Y.E is a game that appeals to a very specific kind of player, generally players who are fans of the first Deus Ex from 2000's. I had to learn this the hard way after suggesting this to many of my friends only for them to judge the game as broken or unfinished. It's not for everyone, and even though I enjoyed this game I can understand why people don't like it.

So what exactly is E.Y.E? E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy is a cyber punk FPS RPG drug trip published and developed by Streum. In E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy you customize your character(s) and shape them into different paths that the game has set for you (and no, you cannot customize your character's gender or body type, it's only on a stat level) The game has quite a learning curve at the very start of the game so when the game throws a needle in your face and tells you to inject yourself full of cybernetic Chi...You pick some traits that sounds cool only to find out you've made the worst character in existance.

You can also select different armor types for whatever playthrough you're going with, such as: Light armor, which allows you to run faster and cloak more effectively but very fragile and next to useless at the end game. It's good for a stealth or Psi run if you are sitting on a large amount of stamina, but that's about it.

Medium armor, a bit slower than light armor but can take a fair amount of punishment. This armor is decent from early to mid game and sometimes late game depending on what role you went with. But chances are you're going to want heavy armor on mars.

And finally Heavy armor, this armor is a little too strong for it's own good. It can tank massive amounts of damage and if you have a chaingun, you might as well be considered a living turret. There isn't a whole lot of mobs in early to mid game that can potentially stop you other than demons. The only flaw to this armor is it's speed, but when you look at the Heavy armor's benefits, it simply makes the game a whole lot easier to play.

The Plot  It's really hard to say what the plot is, or at least where it's going. There are several different theories floating around on the forums and none of which have managed to explain as to what in the hell is going on. You play as some cybernetic ninja/samurai/knight/zombie. And if that hasn't already driven you off then I congratulate you, you are perhaps more devoted to insane indie games than I am.

You wake up from some nightmare (or vision) only to find yourself in a cave cluttered with bodies and blood stains. You then recieve a message from your 'Mentor' saying you need to get out of the cave before the federals find you. Once you have arrived at the HQ you will get a lecture from your mentor about how you were captured and a reminder of the curent state of the proxy war with the two factions within E.Y.E, the Jians and the Culter.

After your chat with him, you are greeted by some kind of floating metal box with a gun attached saying you left a message for yourself.  You learn that you have amneisa (obviously) and that there was a mission on mars that went to hell and back with you somehow in the mix of it.

That's pretty much the easiest to understand. But after that the story itself takes a nose dive into the chaotic storm that is insanity, leaving you with no idea as to what your objective is or why you are doing it.

A lot of players claim that's what makes E.Y.E enjoyable, but I had to play the game in small sips because of the garbled plot. So you better like Source engine, shooting the same models of enemies over and over again, and grinding for research items because the story is not worth paying attention to.

The Game  I'm not going to lie to you, this game is a fresh breath of air in this MoBA/action shooter dominated industry. This game does a good job of creating a unique Cyberpunk setting despite being limited by the constraints of the Source engine. And if there is another E.Y.E installment, I would prefer it still used Source simply because it seems to work well with the game. You also have the advantage of anyone on a potato could play it.

But there are many problems with E.Y.E that make it hard to create an enjoyable experience. First of all the guns and the way they feel are horrible. This is once again, probably because of the Source engine because so far I have yet to play a Source game with satisfying gunplay.

The other flaw with guns is the progression (or the progression of this game in general) in which they are unlocked. The majority of them are already unlocked and most of the default weapons are far better than what you can purchase (excluding the power hammer and the Bear Killer) I'm not sure what the development was like for this game, but this is basic progression logic completely ignored.

Finally the maps- The true problem with the maps in E.Y.E is just the emptiness, there aren't any civilian NPC's (no I am not counting the bandits as civilian NPC's) Without civilians walking around it just takes away the atmosphere. It's that hateful moment when you stop and think oh yeah
date: I'm in a video game..." Hell
recommended: there's even a map called New Eden where you can run into apartments and quickly find out that there is no living human being in a single room.\n\nSpeaking of human population
hoursPlayed: if you aren't fond of the whole "women as trophies" thing then you are not going to like any mission involving bandits. Because a large portion of their quests involve stealing sex slaves or some rubbish like that. Ironically

reviewText: EYE is one of those few games that leaves me severely wanting more but is also almost perfect the way it is. The almost is there because there are some annoying bugs, and you may need to do what I did which is backup the save files every time you exited due to some of the bugs. There was one stage in particular that gave me a great deal of grief, but the elements were there, especially the hacking, and the story kept me interested too. It's true, the story will not make sense even if you do get the 'true' ending, but it's possible to piece together some idea of a story which has worked for games like Killer 7 or Hotline Miami. If you like reading into things and speculating about story, it will probably capture you too. Just look into those bugs and back up from the beginning.

reviewText:
With a very special thanks to RoosterTheRed for proof-reading this review, E.Y.E is a first-person shooter roleplaying game set in a futuristic society in which several factions compete for resources and overall control. You play as a custom character comprised of a chosen set of skills, races, and equipment; as with many other roleplaying titles, these attributes can be altered during the game’s course. Though complex in the beginning, E.Y.E delivers a fantastic overall theme that only enhances the gameplay and in-game decisions. This game includes solo, cooperative, and competitive play options, though it is recommended to play this game with friends or other individuals you know given the fact that the online community is quite scarce in number; this should not be too much of an issue since the base game presents a wide array of playability.
Here are just a few things I found of interest in Blat-Blat: Sneaky Shiz (inside joke):

Roleplaying Aspects - Within E.Y.E’s in-depth theme, described more thoroughly in a further segment) is the ability to generate and decide conflicts as a character of your choosing. There are multiple humanoid racial archetypes you can choose from, and three can be selected in any combination to grant favored bonuses; a guide is heavily recommended for new players deciding on what race or races to be lest their original tabletop, A.V.A, was reviewed. Beyond this elaborate statistics system in which players can assign skills more pertinent to their style of play by allotting points into such expertise as Hacking. As the player gains levels, they may apportion more points into their skills, and specific upgrades and abilities can be purchased if the player’s character has the prerequisite skill efficiency. Throughout the campaign there are many decisions that can be made to influence the remaining story or side quests, which causes the balance between the multiple existing parties to shift slightly. Another interesting topic is Research, which can be performed from the in-game menu at virtually any time. Research grants the player items such as the healing syringe, as well as additional lore and weapons.

Unique Overworld - This title’s theme is widely regarded as steampunk, though I find it to be more reminiscent of Warhammer 40,000’s flavor. Regardless, it maintains a glimpse of a grim future, with rivaling factions, psionic powers, monsters, and magic. Character designs are engaging, and enemy forces are both laughable-referring to the forces with afros-and menacing at times. Scarabs-similar to Skull Servitors in Warhammer 40,000-and other technological advances blend nicely with the atmosphere since a given majority of objects can be hacked or modified. The overworld has a gloomy noir feel to it which amplifies the theme of warring parties while retaining individuality.

Gameplay - E.Y.E melds several interesting components together into one combat system which can be experienced in a variety of ways. Items are displayed in an overly of the character in a depiction as to what they can carry in a grid-based format; this generally means that you can bear as much as can be “on your person.” Gameplay is fluid, with varying forms of firearms and melee weapons at the player’s disposal to aide in eliminating hostiles. The previously described Research system also plays a vital role in weapon selection since weapons and items such as the Gatling gun and medical syringe, respectively, can be developed for use. Players are able to hack objects for certain gains such as opening a secret compartment behind a locked door, and are even able to be hacked back by the object they are targeting; it’s strange but highly humorous. Psionic powers can also be used in combat. Examples of this include creating multiple clones of the player, performing a devastating sprinting melee attack, transmuting all grounded items into health pickups, and passively increasing jump elevation. There are also several purchasable upgrades from venders which add new powers and improve known skills. All of these allow the player to develop their own style of play apart from the usual ‘kill everything that moves and forget anything else’ approach many other first-person shooters adopt.

Hidden Content - Though mostly prompted by side missions, there are many undiscovered bounties stowed around the map. One such is a treasure that few players have discovered-including myself-within the vicinity of a huge map. These objectives add a great amount of depth to E.Y.E, as well as replayability.

TL:DR - E.Y.E offers an enormous amount of content for players who enjoy roleplaying games and intriguing lore combined with a variety of actions, upgrades, and choices in-game. This title does have its quirks in regards to certain features but its gameplay style makes up for this as a motley roleplaying experience unlike many. This title is highly recommended for those who pursue games that blend tactics and combat, as well as those how persistently go out of their way to unravel secrets. Thanks for reading.

Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

reviewText:
Where to ♥♥♥♥ing start?

Okay, the reason I am recomending this game is not necessarily because it has the capacity to be enjoyable, which it totally does, but because this game is just so ♥♥♥♥ing weird that I like it, or I hate it, I'm not quite sure. It is a game that defies criticism and defies review.

The game is absolutely littered with problems and it isn't really designed spectacularly well, yet, just look at it, look at it, with your face, use your eyes and see the mess that is this game. I feel like I am going crazy here. Am I the only one seeing this? They literally included 32 player co-op as a thing because... why the ♥♥♥♥ not? It totally breaks the game but have it anyways.

This is probably the most horrifying thing I have ever played and it isn't trying to be a horror game, it has given me nightmares since I bought it over a year ag because I have literally had panic attacks while playing this game. One of the bullet points on the steam page says, Psychological and mental trauma management
date:
which is totally meant as like a feature of the game but it really means the mental and psychological trauma this game will cause you, in real life, to your sanity. I think I have enough evidence to file for psychological abuse.

You may think I meant for this to be a would not recomend review but no, I totally 100% recomend this game. I sincerely believe everyone should buy and play this game. You just have to see this ♥♥♥♥, it is truly baffling. It's bad but it's good, it's really good. It's a world you will keep coming back to because you want to try to understand it, but you won't, you won't understand it. I know, I've played it. This game is, to me, an example of what all sci-fi should aspire to be, a complete non-sensical mess that gives you more questions than answers.

Oh and I guess there is multiplayer now.

TL;DR - Panic Attack Simulator 2011 GOTY edition

reviewText:
This is an RPG combined with FPS.
It has some great ideas, but they're hard to spot because of overall crudeness.
First and the most annoying: it's dark. Too dark. Unless you're walking with your eye implant always on - you can't see a thing.
Second: lack of descent tutorial and explanation. Here, have this complex game, figure out by yourself how to enjoy it.
Third: I understand that devs wanted to force players to use tactics other than brute force... Well, it's great for hardcore players and all, but there is a huge downside: if you don't know beforehand which tactics you need to use to win this mission, you'll fail. More than once.
Fourth: and here we arrive to ridiculous saving system. Your progress is saved. All the time. But every time you're brought back to the last checkpoint (these are VERY rare). For example: I talked with Mentor during the mission, got a ton of exp, disconnected... Resumed the game and I can talk to Mentor once more to gain ton of exp once more. I just happened to do that 5 or so times.

reviewText: The trailers suggest that EYE is an indie Deus Ex, allowing varied playing styles. Sadly this isn’t true. It’s combat heavy with constantly respawning enemies. The cloak runs out too quickly, the maps are huge with wide open spaces and not enough cover, to make stealth a viable tactic. The plot doesn’t make sense to me, partly due to a poor translation from the native French language resulting in NPC dialogue lacking proper grammar, and partly because allies give updated orders during missions while you’re too busy trying to not die, so it’s hard to concentrate on what is being said, and every mission becomes a case of just following the waypoint marker and shooting some guys or pressing a button without ever really knowing why. Yes, there are some complex character stats and abilities and the shooting is okay, but nowhere near as entertaining as Serious Sam for mindless violence. Ultimately I can only recommend EYE on a Steam sale if you’ve got nothing better to play.

reviewText:
Many people buy this game thinking they're buying a System Shock or a Deus Ex. Maybe a Borderlands or a STALKER. This is an incorrect assumption to make. It's true that EYE features many RPG elements. It has dialogue, branching paths, levels, inventory management, stores and side-missions. But this is all plays second fiddle to what EYE is really aiming for. It's not a Deus Ex as much as it is a Serious Sam. It's not a Borderlands as much as it is a Painkiller. I really cannot emphasize this enough, it's my belief that the majority of the complaints directed towards EYE stem from a false presupposition of what this game is trying to be. That is not the players fault though, because EYE doesn't exactly make these things clear.

EYE is a mess.

Unless you are a Dwarf Fortress player, EYE is likely to be the biggest, messiest game you are ever likely to see. Right off the bat it gives you a character creation screen which makes absolutely no sense to anyone beginning the game without first googling what in the hell you are looking at. The dialogue is either intentionally vague, bizarre and most of the time incomprehensible. You will be thrown into a world which appears to have some sort of lore and backstory but you'll be lucky if you ever understand a tenth of what is going on. When the game presents you with the tutorial level, many aspects of that tutorial will need tutorials themselves, and you will be confronted with a library of tutorial videos on how certain game mechanics work. Your body can be hacked and destroyed by doors and ATMs. Sometimes huge monsters will appear in the level and fire rockets in directions you didn't even know existed and you have to kill it. Sometimes you'll be tasked to kill a high ranking enemy and he will zip about the game shooting and cloaking tanking hits like nothing else. This game is primarily single-player, but you can have 64-player coop. You can buy spells and augmentations and guns and big hammers all with a currency called Brozouf which you seem to endlessly gain in areas where you are doing something for some reason for someone. EYE is a deranged and twisted mess of Syndicate, Neuromancer, Warhammer 40k and the entire personal drug stash of Hunter S. Thompson. And you know what? It's amazing.

There is no messing around with regenerating health, cover or killcams. You can go in fast and furious or heavy like robocop. The guns feel like they should. There is real impact when you shoot something. Enemies will go flying across the screen. You can teleport into people and laugh as they explode. You can hit people in the face with giant hammers and watch as they bounce off the walls. You can hack people. You can force push four-armed creatures into radioactive goo. You can block bullets with swords. This game can be anything you want, but above all it is satisfying.

If you get this game, it's imperative that you know what you getting into. If you want a cyberpunk dystopia with thought provoking dialogue and choices that mean something, I don't advise you to get this game. If you want a crazy FPS that is a completely unapologetic mess that explains nothing but offers everything then I would strongly recommend this game.

reviewText: Ah, this title is a devisive one.\n\nIf you want to have a game with fun, tight, intense shooting, atmospheric enviornments, lots of ways to accomplish objectives, non-linear gameplay, and really in-depth systems, then pick this one up. However, if you're getting it to recieve gripping story and/or narrative, user friendliness, or just polish in general, then I wouldn't recommend this one. It's simple as that, really. If you do plan on picking it up, prepare yourself for the learning curve- it's pretty brutal. Nevertheless, I enjoy the game. It was worth the dollar I spent on it.

Reviewing a game like E.Y.E comprehensively isn't an easy task, none the less lets have a stab at it.

The game makes a thematic spin on a common premise:
- You are a super soldier with Amnesia
- There is a war going on
- You are going to kill your way to victory in FPS glory

This is where is leaves the standard model behind both in gameplay, aesthetic, theme and story.

From a Gameplay perspective all skills and utilities are provided as a means of killing things. Even the medkit can be used to overdose someone.
Hacking? use it to fry someone's brain or turn them crazy and make them attack their colleagues.
Magic? Create a clone army of yourself and send them in to battle, or if you prefer the direct approach just teleport yourself inside" your target enemy and make them explode.
Stealth? Cloak up
recommended:
snipe people or slit their throats (or crush them with a hammer... or crush them by falling on them super-mario style)
Guns? Guns.

reviewText:
A delicious game that took many by surprise, E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is one of those purchases that will keep you coming back for more.

What you need to know:

Amazing use of the Source engine, sporting great visuals and environments.  Even the weapons have several animation states!

Sounds are pleasing, and the soundtrack is VERY pleasing.  (Though, you will have to dig into the game files to grab the music.)

Melee weapons, handguns, rifles, shotguns, high-explosives, and even a hammer.  Not to mention crazy psychic voodoo-magic.  Also you can clone yourself, and your clones will even level up based on your stats, as well.

Some great, uh, voiceacting.  Trust me, you'll find it quite amusing at times.

Gameplay is excellent.  Hacking is a challenge, and the gunplay is satisfying.  Also, you can kill people by throwing hamburger boxes at high speeds and that's funny to me.

Standalone missions to play outside of story mode even support randomized enemy spawns, and random-picked objectives.

And to add to that, cooperative mode allows many players to play through the story mode seamlessely.

Lots of achievements, if you're into that.

---------------

The downsides:

A blast in singleplayer, but the game truly becomes a gem with friends.

The translation quality on ingame texts is.. err..

It can take some time to find the randomly-dropping researches, and money grows on your character a bit slowly.  Dying is EXTREMELY dangerous, as it can apply perma-debuffs to your character's stats.  That is, until you sink enough time and money into research to prevent them entirely.

Community for it is a bit stagnant, and while custom maps are possible, pretty much none exist.

Multiplayer PVP feels strange, and multiplayer itself has some odd bugs.  IE: Lives are shared across all players, meaning somebody dying multiple times can kick EVERYONE back to the lobby map.  Some maps even end up killing the host when a client dies in some areas.

All physics objects also effect other players, so you CAN kill someone else with a high-velocity object, even if PVP is disabled.  Oh, all NPC's (even friendly ones!) are affected by damage, so it's easy for one player to null-void the entire lobby map of NPC's to buy from.  Ouch.

Re-playability tends to DIE after some time of playing it, but it has enough to offer to make you come back after a while as well.  (You'll probably get tons of hours through a single chunk of playing through it all, though.  Even more with friends!)

---------------

All in all, great game.  REALLY glad I was able to play this, and hope you will too.

reviewText:
So let's try writing some review for these games I have. Anyways,

E.Y.E. You're a stupidly wierd game.

Good:
The gameplay is fun for what it is, and I never got tired of the cool factor of being able to block machine gun fire with my sword or being able to hack into someone's skull to make them explode. Couple of other gadgets you start with too, and you have quite a few upgrades and new guns you can get that may or may not be fun to use. It never really gets painfully hard either, which I consider a redeeming factor for this incoherent game.

There are plenty of free missions and locales that you can play, several fun to use weapons, pyschic powers, a campaign that doesn't overstay it's welcome, and an awesome atmosphere that is both tense and unsettling. The entire setting has a nice cyberpunk feel to it, and there's plenty of cool factor to spare.

Bad:
If you are expecting any kind of story to enjoy than good luck. Confusing English and a lack of explanation makes the story hard to follow at best. It doesn't help that the story plays with some insanity tropes as well; making things even more confusing. The rpg mechanics are worthless, and I never really felt like I became anything special aside from just a samurai guy. Some of the systems like magic/psychic power feels underdeveloped, and the insanity thing, which actually is an interesting mechanic for the game, can be removed by an 'upgrade'. As far as combat goes: the A.I. is ridiculous. One little detection can result in the entire enemy army walking in a straight line towards your location. There is also this weird critical hit/negative hit system, but I've killed enemies in one hit with a Failed Attack" several times so I don't know what to make of that. Overall
date:
The whole thing just feels marred by poor design choices.

The story is confusing as a story can get. The core rpg mechanics lack complexity. There are way too dang many large empty areas. A.I. is clumsy at best. And you'll probably go through the whole game without buying or upgrading anything. Don't expect to be impressed anywhere here; there's just a lot of boring trash beneath a paper thin shine.

Overall:
It's a game you have to play simply for the experience. Just to play for the overall unique strangeness of the setting. To get sucked in to the weirdness of the story about a cybernetic super samurai who may or may not be insane. It has it's cool moments to help things a long too
hoursPlayed: you start with a sword that can block pretty much anything and sets people on fire.\n\nBut
voteText: if you are expecting a solid experience then you probably won't be amused by this at all. The game requires you to overlook a lot of problems. If it were even a little bit better I would change my overall opinion here. But there is just nothing to guarantee you will like this
helpfulPercent: so that's why I would not recommend it."

reviewText:
The game struck me a cross between Ghost in the Shell and Deus Ex fighting in Total Recall.

There is a great deal of build customization to suit your playstyle from jaunting sniper to ogre brute with a sword. The tutorial is not very helpful at all. If you don't like trial and error tinkering you should probably go straight to a guide for mechanics and loadout.

I enjoyed the game for its novelty and variety of playstyles but ultimately abandoned it. For some reason any lenghty gameplay sessions left me with some annoying headaches (literally, not sure if it was the lighting or the movement).

I can't really recommend this game unless your a big fan of the dystopian sci-fi genre or are looking for something different to play and want something like Fallout in an Unreal Tournament world with tighter gunplay and less need for talking.

reviewText:
This game is hard to get into, hard to master, and for most people the first hours are a real pain in the ♥♥♥ . Yes, you´ll either love it or hate it, it´s a very unique game.

<<<<<THE BEGINNING>>>>>

You are thrown into a world you probably wouldn´t imagine in your weirdest weed-caused dreams. You are a guy who lost all his memories (yes, this setting is very commonly used;). You make your way out of a dark cave, where you get attacked by the first enemy: a rather small two-legged red monster spitting fireballs.

After some minutes in, you realize that somehow the cave leads to the very top of a industrial building used as Military base. You gear up: Double Katanas, Pistols, , Revolvers, MGs, Assault rifles, Sniper Rifles, do you want Armor? A light, medium or heavy one? Drones? Medipacks? Remote Turrets? Grenades?)

You then kill some old-fashioned fallout-like brotherhood-of-steel guys who decided to spend their free time and roam around in a lonely cold wet canal next to the building complex. Jump into the sewers, bash annoying punks there, get out, make an attempt to hack a door but fail desperately the first time, get hacked back by the door as you think

What am I doing here?!"

At this point

reviewText:
In my highschool P.E. class we would go to the local bowling alley sometimes. We would take the school's bus and my friend would always sit in the same exact seat. The seats were made of foam and covered in a fake-leather material. My friend would always poke at a tear on the seat in front of him, but I initially thought nothing of it. This is important.

The bowling alley had a food court near the entrance with a bunch of packets of condiments. My friend would always grab a handfull or two of them and stuff them into his pockets on the way out. One day back on the bus I noticed my friend poking at the hole on the seat again, and he started emptying into it  the contents of the mayonaise and ketchup packets he took from the bowling alley.

I asked him what he was doing and he only said, It's the sauce hole."

Also E.Y.E. is pretty good."

reviewText:
E.Y.E is not a game for the light-hearted, but can easily be fun when you have a solid grip on it's mechanics. If you're just starting out, you'll notice there is a fairly large and extensive RPG element despite this being an Action/FPS title. Do not be overwhelmed! This game is simply trying newer things and mixing up the genre a bit. You can use money you've gained to research new weapons, better abilities, and better cybernetic implants. Your character slowly becomes this god-like being whether you just want to run'n'gun or be more ninja like. Either way, what's infront of you usually dies. A very ambitious title.
Not to mention that there are branching story archs.

The artwork and design is a well blended cluster of Warhammer meeting Cyber-Punk. The weapons feel heavy and powerful. The cities have smog and droopy colors. Everything comes together really giving the world this depressing hell was already here" look.

Sadly
date: the Source engine begins to show it's age. That didn't stop the great map development or modelers though. Bugs tend to still pop up and physics can go haywire
recommended: but that has not stopped me from enjoying 200+ hours of entertainment. I bought this years ago and still enjoy it. Even if it isn't on sale
hoursPlayed:
I would recommend this game. I can only pray for a solid sequel. I even see this on sale for $1 USD every now and again. Don't let the price tag fool you. It's way beyond a bargain (if you're willing to let go of what you already knew about the FPS genre).

Get it.
Love it.
"

reviewText:
I'll be frank...this game has a lot of potential. Its only real draw to me is it's like Deus Ex... if Deus Ex was a horribly translated, pretty shotty source mod and hadn't been funded by some pretty large companies at the time. That being said, what there is to the game is fun. E.Y.E. boasts nice multiplayer, interesting leveling systems, a cool crafting system but is plagued with issues like limited enemies and the quickly dying out source engine. As much as source has brought us joy and happiness, it just isn't modern game material, even back in 2011.

With all of those factors in place, the enemies can be ridiculously easy, often running around randomly into tactically horrid spots. The hacking in the game is another game to its self, like a small RPG that is played in a minute or so. The Tutorials are also extremely lengthy, have no sound, and because of the communication gap caused by the games horrible translation, hard to follow. The story is told to you through your collegues and mentors since you for some reason have amnesia, which is one drawn out story mechanic this game could have done without.

Overall the game is a fun tech demo, if source wasn't already out for almost a decade, I would have been wow'd by this. It's a good buy if you can get it for $5 or less, but definitely isn't worth the $10 price tag.

reviewText:
You’re a full-on medieval knight (like on a ♥♥♥♥ing horse medieval, like ye olde english medieval) who is a member of, I guess you call it a cult, which is operating in Blade Runner/Neotokyo setting. This cult is run by, get this, ♥♥♥♥ing space marines from Warhammer. To be precise by two space marines from Warhammer who are constantly at each others throats. The cult itself is at war with CYBER CHINESE WHO ARE PART OF THE SAME ♥♥♥♥ING CULT. The cult is also at war with the government and the government is at war with ♥♥♥♥ing everyone.

It gets better. The starting location is uh I think it’s your dead cyber-brain which is pierced by ♥♥♥♥huge katanas and the dead bodies of the two key space marines are there too. There’s also a cyber chinese dude who is I think an intentional reference to Morrowind’s Jiub. The chinese dude appears there only when you die. Death mechanics are really interesting, basically you can be resurrected by your implant called Resurrector but the number of resurrections is FINITE, when you die for real you get back to the katanas and ♥♥♥♥ in the DREAM.

But wait there’s more. The first tutorial starts in PLATO’S CAVE. Yep. I guess this is the only time my philosophy class came in handy. All those sleepless fresman nights, the professor had us manually copying all of Plato’s works in the notebooks for a whole ♥♥♥♥ing year. There are shadows and I guess what passes for prisoners and I guess you get the knowledge of the true reality right from the start but… I don’t even ♥♥♥♥ing know man.

There’s also Captain Dutch, who is the only character who’s not a huge ♥♥♥♥ to me in this game. I mean those space marines are ♥♥♥♥ing insufferable.

reviewText: Cyberpunk action role playing game with very odd gameplay, kill anyone at any time, hack or be hacked, farming experience is based on dealing deadly damage instead of killing your enemy. Huge and hallow maps with few enemies in each of them, but luckily game has unique feature which allows to reinforce enemy squads that makes game more enjoyable. Also it has very deep character skill trees, that requires lot of time to test them all. The game suffers from lack of explinations and tips, not to mention there are no map nor radar, which causes to player to get stuck or lost most of time. Strongly recommend playing it on coop that will give you most fun, single player not so much.

reviewText:
E.Y.E is essentially a Deus Ex in terms of its FPS/RPG style and its numerous ways to approach an objective. This game is translated from French, so the dialog is a bit iffy at times. The game is based on a Source mod, so the graphics are slightly dated, if that sort of thing is important to you over actual gameplay. Easily overlooked, however, by its other fantastic points.

Given its complexity, one could call E.Y.E a true PC game. It has a moderate learning curve, along with several skills and different paths/classes to potentially follow. You can pick up drops from dead enemies that contribute to a wide-scale researching system to upgrade your character overall. You can also upgrade your character's implants, anything from improved legs to increase running speed and jumping height, to your nervous system to improve hacking and reflex speed.

E.Y.E's developers are very much on top of the game as well, having released a 1GB patch shortly after its release that fixed several bugs.

reviewText:
Hoo boy. This is why I love independent games.

Not going to lie. This game is rough. It has issues. But you know what? It's easy to overlook because of how ambitious it is.

In this game you play an agent in a shadowy organization dedicated to fighting... you know what? I don't even know what the plot is. There's infighting in the organization. It's distracting from your true purpose of combating a corrupting force. There is background text that hints at a complex setting, though it doesn't have much impact on what you will experience in the assorted missions.

The plot itself is a complete head trip. And the ending gets really meta.

In terms of game play, it's a first person shooter. You get money and in between missions you can unlock items. You have a number of inventory slots on your person you can place those items in.  You gain experience, and levels, which you can use to improve skills. You also can purchase cybernetic implants and psionic abilities. There's a lot of ways you can pull your character. But you probably want to decide exactly what they are ahead of time because it doesn't pay to generalize.

There are a number of glitches and exploits in the game. And it can be a bit of a grind. Very much a wiki game.

Has a cooperative multiplayer mode, and you retain your progress in both.

reviewText:
E.Y.E. is a hybrid RPG-FPS that tries to re-capture the feeling of Deus Ex using the Source engine and WH40k aesthetics. Does it work though? Partially. The stealth aspect is heavily nerfed in comparison to Deus Ex and most of the time you have to brute-force your way in, but still the game delivers what made Deus Ex good - freedom of approaching your objectives and battles. Add a layer of upgrades, customizability and good weapon selection and you have a rather solid gameplay.

But E.Y.E. is not an easy game. It will take at least 2-3 failed attempts to understand how to play it properly. Even with the cheat sheets, it's very easy to misunderstand basic concepts and utilities role. The difficulty ramps up very quickly and by 3rd level it's very easy to get overwhelmed if you're inexeprienced. But once you master the system, the game delivers an amazing experience in terms of many builds you can use. The three main systems - guns, hacking and spells can be used seprately or merged and more often you'll find yourself trying to find a fun build that is in line with your playstyle rather than making a jack-of-all character.

On the narrative side, E.Y.E.'s broken English and dialogue choices that range from a calm responses to psychotic threats of violence certain give the game a really weird flavour to it. Some of the messages you get in game You gain Brouzouf"
date: "My legs are OK" and "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T! Ultra-failed attack!" have become loved by the E.Y.E. community to the point that no discussion is complete without copious amount of Brozouf
recommended: checking your legs and making sure your attacks are not Ultra-failed. There is a story hidden behind that facade of poorly translated writing
hoursPlayed: but it takes a little bit to get to it. It feels more like a forgein film than anything in that manner - it's rough around the edges but ultimately it's enjoyable after watching it twice.\n\nIt's really hard to describe E.Y.E. - what started out as a clunky
voteText: buggy mess of a game with some patching and community turned into one of the "Must-played" cult games. E.Y.E. is an experience. A wonderful experience in the most psychodelic gaming trip you can ever imagine.\n\nI recommend it."

reviewText:
To be technical, it's an FPSRPG with all the usual flair of stats and cybernetic upgrades, inventory etc.

Apart from that it's probably the weirdest game I've played in a while. It doesn't seem to follow any of the usual rules of modern game design and ends up feeling very fresh because of it. But the weirdness is almost certainly going to cause the lowest common denominator hate it because, well, it's not easily accessible.

The setting is, as someone put it, a mix of Deus Ex, Warhammer 40k, Stalker and a whole slew of 1980's scifi films. Some of the maps would not look at all out of place in a Blade Runner game, for example.

Given how cheap the game is, especially when on sale, I just have to recommend it. Even if you are disappointed, you won't be down too many bucks for it, and I can pretty much guarantee that you've not played anything quite like it before.

reviewText: A strange mix of Deus Ex and Serious Sam. Not only is it aesthetically influenced by films such as Ghost in the Shell, Blade Runner and Alien, but it is influenced sonically too. Highly recommended to all shooter and RPG fans who don't mind something a little rough around the edges, or hard to understand.

reviewText: My god, do I have mixed feelings about this game.  It clearly ran out of money half way through its development and it has some unbelievably annoying glitches all throughout.  (I also have some problems with certain parts of the story, but in the interest of not giving spoilers to a very story intensive game I won't bring them up here.)  Still, for as annoying as this games flaws can get, they are completely outshown by the amazing, deep experience this game provides.  With the single best Cyberpunk world I've ever heard of, a fascinating (if flawed) story, and the best gameplay in a serious shooter I've ever experienced, I can only recommend this game to shooter fans and RPG fans alike.  (Oh, did I mention they have a really fun and (mostly) balanced character specialization and weapons system?  'Cause that's really important.)  I think my friend put it best; this game does tacticool" flawlessly.  Be warned; it's very challenging and it does glitch on occasion.  That said
date: this is one of the best games I've ever played and one of my favorite of all time."

reviewText:
EYE is a source engine game, meaning you'll find the playstyle reminicent to that of Half Life, Left for Dead, etc. But that's just the tip of the iceberg as far as gameplay goes because on top of being a FPS, this game also has RPG elements. You have stats that benefit your melee damage, accuracy, hacking, run speed, Psychic powers, and so on. On top of that you can spend ludicrous amounts of money to get cyber body modifications or to preform research on artifacts which will boost your stats even higher. At a certain point you will be able to run at ridiculous speeds, turn your foes into a fine red mist with a cybernetic claymore, and backstab helicopters with warhammers.

However there are a few places where it, debatibaly, falls short. There are a lot of bugs in the game, not including the ones that you can shoot. Even with an extensive ingame tutorial a lot of gameplay mechanics are somewhat unclear. Every character in the game talks and swears like a grizzled bandit, from actual grizzled bandits to your fellow psychic space illuminati assassin paladins. A karma and rating system that 'somehow' are intregal to gameplay probably. Getting shot in the face so hard that it breaks your legs, you get the idea.

The story is an absolute trip, even if you do get the final ending there's a lot that you probably wont grasp. With elements such as alternate/nonexistant timelines, internal conflict in past-present tense, and the psychic force of the universe lashing out in the form of monstrosities in retaliation to rapid cyberascension and the squelching out of other species. I honestly have no idea what's going on and neither will you. Shut up and gain brozouf.

reviewText:
Nobody could possibly argue that EYE is a perfect game.  It feels and looks like an unpolished half life mod at first, but despite its flawed execution of a cyberpunk-rpg shooter, EYE immerses you in its story and atmosphere.

Pros:
-Cyberpunk
-Interesting character building with cyberkinetics and psi abilities
-Dirt cheap during sales
-You gain brouzouf

Cons:
-Empty MP servers (mostly)
-Combat during early levels can be frustrating (armored enemies)
-AI is wierd, can make stealth unviable

reviewText:
I purchased this game two hours prior to writing this review. I paid 99 cents for it. I've played it for less than half an hour.

In that half an hour, I walked through a portal, found myself in an ugly cave, fought an ugly beast, spent a significant number of minutes trying to understand confusing tutorials, cursed the horrible menu design, dual-wielded katanas, shot some dudes in the face, shot some more dudes in the face with a different gun after stabbing some other dude in the back, almost got killed by a sniper, leveled up some abilities, made it to a friendly temple, accidentally punched a friendly guy in the face, and proceeded to get murdered 4 times in a row while trying to figure out how to tell the exceptionally large number of people shooting at me that I didn't mean it.

10/10... would get murdered repeatedly while not understanding a single thing that's happening again.

reviewText:
Recommended but only just.

The Good:

The story is certainly interesting
The settings are also interesting
Cyber Ninja powers (!)
Certain sections look very nice indeed

The Meh:

The controls are funky and rebinding them is almost mandatory
The graphics in the majority of places are atrocious for a 2011 release and could easily be from 2003
The gun and sword play is decidely average

The Bad:

The ******* translation. To say it is bad would be an understantment. For a story as conveluted as E.Y.E.'s you have to be able to read the text with minimal difficulty. I believe the studio is French but that is no excuse. England is only 30 minutes away!

The world is empty. Oh, sure, there are monsters and bad guys aplenty but there is no one else around at all. It feels extremely lifeless and isolating.

The AI is below average. If you are not behind something. or cloaked, the enemy will magically turn on the spot and come straight for you with guns blazing.

Infinitely spawning enemies. 'Nuff said.

Conclusion:

With the current trend of remaking everything, from classic games to film franchises, E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy would be a prime target for such treatment. Updated graphics, AI, translation etc could easily put this game in contention for GotY.

I may have listed quiet a few negatives there, and they can be extremely aggrevating,  but, for those willing to push on through, you can find the sparks of a great game and I do recommend giving it a fair shot.

reviewText:
As a wandering Space Illuminati Knight Samurai Magician Predator-alien with amnesia you find yourself questioning your role in the Space Illuminati and how the other faction of Space Illuminati Kung-Fu Samurai Sorcerer Ninjas intertwine with your destiny, as a man who writes his own destiny in the neon golden blood of the Space Illuminati temple he lives in, which he calls his soul.

E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is a FPS/RPG most comparable to Deus Ex gameplay mixed with Source engine physics, Warhammer 40K aesthetics and a story that's meant to be as confusing as possible.

The story revolves around power struggles. Between governments and rebel organizations, between different factions in the same organization, between members within the same faction, and ultimately power struggles within individuals. There are multiple endings and the player has a choice in what factions to side with or betray as well as how they want to accomplish the tasks they've been given.

The gameplay is a mix between an FPS and an RPG. You have stats and classes but how well you can point a gun still determines whether you will hit or miss. Your stats affect everything from your ability to use weapons to how prone to hallucinations your character is. It's likely you will be overrun by the amount of stats the game throws at you. You character has weapon/item unlocks, armor types, robotic implants, research, cybernetic upgrades, stats, and semi-permanent debuffs to deal with. Because each of these affects other stats in one of 4 different ways. using a guide isn't a shameful thing in this game when it comes to understanding mechanics.

One the FPS side of things it's pretty satisfying and in-depth too. There are keys to lean your character left/right, and they are used often. The guns are also satisfying, whether they're the default ones or higher tiered unlocks. Admittedly all of the guns are crazy accurate, even with a fairly low accuracy stat. Firing in bursts will keep most guns at a near sniper rifle accuracy due to this. Movement can be anywhere from ponderously slow to Arena FPS fast depending upon your equipment weight and your speed, with jump height ranging from a measly little hop to a 4 story leap. Psi powers are the only other thing to talk about and they keep with the weird over the top action by allowing you to literally make enemies explode into red mist before teleporting to their location or just letting a werewolf explode out of their chest and eat their friends.

Overall, the game feels like a neon colored, futuristic Bruce Lee movie with robots, demons, robot-demons, afros, garbled English, confusing choose-your-own-adventure book plots ripe with betrayal, and werewolves. Considering it's often below the $5 mark how can you pass that up?

reviewText: Up is down, and down is up. Left is right and right is wrong, you dream while conscious and the wall between reality and daydreams becomes thinner and thinner with each passing hour. You think you know who you are, what you are, when you are and if you are, but you're wrong about all of that. Or are you? You're not very sure, because maybe you bought this game thinking it was just going to be Deus Ex with multiplayer. What you think might be a story is a distant fog you can't quite grasp, and treading through it only gets you lost. You don't know who you are, what you are, where you are, when you are or even if you are. All you know is that you're playing a game with fantastic gunplay, awesome psychic skills, multiple interesting possible playstyles, many long-term consequences and it just leaves you begging to come back for more. Not to mention the extra difficult levels to truly test your skill, and not to mention, potentially 32 person multiplayer. But this game is complex, and may not be for you. You may simply not be able to grasp it, but you have to try. This game is utterly fantastic. And for its price, absolutely worth it.

reviewText:
Freakily addictive for a game that's wierd as all hell. There's nothing to compare it to, because there's nothing that it's like.

It looks Warhammer 40k-ish, but plays a lot closer to Deus Ex. The story is what you'd get if Tolstoi had just finished reading the Bourne series, if it was set in the Fallout universe, and he'd been mainlining LSD the whole way. I've played the game twice through, and I'm still trying to work out WTF is going on... but in a really good way... was I dreaming? Hallucinating? Jacked into the Matrix?! Also, WTH hasn't my character put his pistol in his mouth just to make it all stop, please, mommy!

The graphics are pretty reasonable, but the sound can get a bit repetitive and the voice-acting is... well... none of it's in English, so I've got no idea whether it's good but intentionally odd" or just badly done. My only real complaint is that very little is explained. Don't even bother with the tutorials
date: they're utterly useless. Your best bet is to work it out yourself with some online research to give you a boost.\n\nAll in all
recommended: it's totally worth the price if you're looking for a fairly competent shooter with substantial RPG elements
hoursPlayed: and a massive dose of WTF that will leave you scratching your head for ages."

reviewText:
TL:DR at the end, scored 5 / 10 as of 26th April 2015
Borba likes:Genre - First Person Shooter melded with RPG elements that seems inspired by Deus Ex, System Shock and a hint of X-Com, carrying a great deal of depth through stats, abilities, research and bodypart upgrades.

Replayability - Open ended gameplay with replayable levels holding different missions and objectives. The story also has a few different endings and meaningful choices. Cooperative and competitive multiplayer also add to the longevity of the title. Also, achievements.

Gameplay - Melee combat and shooting make up for most of the game, and are enjoyable once the character becomes stronger and the player figures a build that suits his playstyle. Blocking bullets with swords, dual-wielding, rapid movement and stealth are few of the many possibilities.

Music - Music blends in nicely without being distracting.

Sound - The sound effects are decent, just not extraordinary.
Borba dislikes:Design - A frustrating early game experience due to lack of a better tutorial makes out for a terrible learning curve, relying on community guides and / or patience. Poor level design, with several maze-like levels that offer little in terms of navigation other than a waypoint without trail. Grindy at times, mostly because almost every mission throws dozens of enemies at the player, and keeps spawning them over and over, which feels like a cheap way to keep the player busy while chugging along the overly large and often confusing levels.

Graphics - Cyberpunk with a touch of the occult, spoiled by Washed out textures that contrast with the better looking character models.

Interface - Non-intuitive interface that will require time and effort to get used to, but will never feel right.

Narrative - Poor writing and dialogues, sometimes even confusing, which is a shame since the game is pretty heavy on text. At times I had the feeling two completely different writters got their works mixed up.

Polish - Bugs and lack of polish, such has having enemies spawn on top of you from a fixed spawn point, ability shortcuts not working and not knowing what researched entries provide until they are researched.


Borba feels like the game can be either loved or hated, providing high value and replayability only to those who can dismiss its raw state and shortcomings. He didn't enjoy it too much though,playing through it fueled by little more than a spark of curiosity felt more of a chore than anything, and for this reason he can't recommend the game.

5/10

reviewText:
Some call it a diamond in the rough. Others call it a piece of crap with redeeming factors. Still others call it a work of genius with deprecating factors. I call it one of the best video games of all time. Play this. Buy this. Love this.

This is the worst game I have ever played in my life, what the ♥♥♥♥ is this ♥♥♥♥? Why is it so badly translated. What the ♥♥♥♥ is wrong with the NPCs, how do I even play this. What is my life? Help me. This is the worst. Don't ever get this game.

In all seriousness, this is the most seriously polarizing thing ever to come out. Be cautious on whether or not to spend your money on it. I loved it to DEATH. But I was kinda lucky in understanding it. I made stupid guesses and they paid off. It's fun when you figure it out tho.

reviewText:
It seems like I almost loved this game, but something just went wrong at the right time, and I felt into hatredness to it.
Let's just pass this out: E.Y.E. is still UNfinished game. For me, it's complete up to 70-80%, and looks more like a raw kickstarter project, than actually like a game.

Firstly, about setting. It looks pretty awesome, story written good, but GOOD GOD HOW BORING IS IT. You have to read TONNS of text, with no sound reaching your ears except for in-game music(Which is not compared to anything, so you can replace it with Sabaton/Slayer/Marylin Manson/Elvis/etc., and it will still be OK). When you're out the first chapter of the game, you feel yourself playing old school text RPG, not modern Source-based FPS. I mean, in Fallout 1-2 was even a usable textbox, from where you were able to read comfortably. And what we've got here? Insane microscopical font. Need to click every single text message to get another. IT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA, STREUM ON.

Secondly, about gameplay. You saw that trailer, showing a lot of options, how to eliminate a single target?
Forget it. All you have to do is to pick up heavy armor, take your faithful stock minigun, and go ♥♥♥♥ everything in sight. I tell you, it works perfectly on ANY KIND OF AN ENEMY. Seriously, what the hell did developers even think of? I tried playing stealth - it's hard and painful, you get yourself ♥♥♥♥♥ by infinitely spawning enemies in ~2 min. I tried playing as silent sniper - it's not hard, but it still will heat your lower back" part of a body

reviewText:
I find it hard to recommend this game, not cause it isn’t good but because it’s a game you have to get into to find the good in it.
It’s hidden behind an almost incomprehensible story, unexplained mechanics and a tutorial system which shouldn’t exist and to some degree doesn’t.
But I have had some amazing fun playing this game just because of what a couple of friends and I have been able to do in it. From trying to survive in an all-out war to sneaking around trying to stay hidden from enemies who will literally one shot us.
If you ever play this game and I wholeheartedly hope you do, I personally recommend playing it with friends maybe one who has played it before so they can give you an idea of how to play fully or just with a bunch of people to try and find out the mechanics yourself.
