reviewText:
Its great, its RPG elements are pretty deep, almost having a Fallout-ish feel to them. It has mechanics from Deus Ex, like its Cyber Tech and Hacking elements.  Another thing it takes from popular RPGs is its inventory system. You have a limited amount of space, so you cant just carry everything around.

Character creation is not very big, it doesn't let you create the physical appearance of your character, but its not needed, because you never see his face. You choose 3 genes to splice together to make your character, each one having a positive and negative effects on your different stats.

It has a speech system not unlike the AAA RPG franchises. It consists of choosing dialogue options and seeing what they have to say about it.  If you anger a character, he might get annoyed with you and tell you to shove off, or even attack the player.

I haven't played it all that much, but with my time spent in Skyrim, Dragon Age, Mass Effect, and Fallout, I know i'm gonna love this game. I highly suggest checking it out.

reviewText:
I played the demo and was immediately hooked. Bought the full game and, even though I'm only a few hours in, I already love it. I do advise you download a text mod that better translates and otherwise explains aspects of the gameplay mechanics and story, but regardless this game has a bit of a learning curve.

Let's get one thing out of the way - this is a shooter first, with RPG elements. The general combat is pretty straightforward. The weapons are fairly point and shoot, but are affected by stance and the Accuracy stat. I haven't tried melee combat much since I'm more of the marksman type, but the swords do hack off limbs nicely. :D The nuance comes from the cyber and psi powers as well as the hacking, which are all governed by a surprisingly expansive stat system. Level ups occurr fairly often (my advice - use a sniper rifle and go for headshots as much as possible, lots of XP!), and there are a variety of skills to upgrade, in addition to new abilities to buy and upgrade, as well research projects to undergo which yield new items and stat bonuses. Point is, this system is much more fun to play with and certainly more fleshed out than other Role-Playing Shooters. It's closer to Deus Ex 1 than it is to, say, Mass Effect 2.

Beyond the game mechanics themselves though, I find myself drawn in to the world. The mix of Templar-ish Culters with the Oriental/Samurai-like Jin factions of the player's organization is really cool, and contributes to a multicultural feeling that extends to the streets of the game's world, which itself is patrolled by ragtag-looking looters and the glowy-eyed stormtroopers of the Federation. As far as rundown, gloomy cyberpunk worlds go, E.Y.E. has it down pat.

I highly encourage you to pony up the meager fee to check out this little gem. It has its flaws to be sure; understanding the world and history requires lots of front-loaded reading in the Temple archives, the A.I. isn't the best and you may want to remap some of the default controls, but in a sea of Source shooters, this 12-man effort stands above as one of the best. E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy restores my faith that there are still people out there who appreciate a good single player RPG.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
E.Y.E. is unlike anything you will ever play.

Let me start out by saying this game is VERY confusing, even with tutorials you will still be lost. It took me quite awhile to understand the basics of the game. Any ailiments you encounter remember to press C, it is a life saver.

The game is set in a futuristic cyberpunk world, with some very impressive levels, Great care and love was put into this games setting. Half of the time playing I would set there being in awe, the city levels in particular are gorgeous.

The gameplay itself is where the game really shines, nothing is more satisfying than cutting an enemy with a sword only for them to explode into pieces. Any enemy you killed gains you brouzoufs, which can be used for different upgrades or can be used for research to increase your stats.

One of my main gripe is the hacking part of the game, nothing about it was enjoyable which can lead to some frustrating encounters. If you failing hacking your character can be killed, so you have to watch your hp all the time.

If you can look past some of it's problem, you've got a real hidden gem on your hands.

reviewText:
The best way to look at a game like EYE: Divine Cybermancy is through the lens of a person who has not played any other game. Ever.

Why? Because it doesn't make any sense. The game deviates so much from the norm, that it would be impossible to compare it to any other game. It isn't really an FPS, nor an RPG, but it has some of both. The story is... satisfactory. It is one of the only games I've played where it hurt to follow the story, but this was only because of my previous experiences with games. Through a lens of a person who hasn't played a game before, the story is fantastic and deep. The rest is average. Playing with other people is semi-fun, servers are semi-populated, and the graphics are semi-good. My legs are okay.

So why is this a positive review? Well, first and foremost, I had to change my perspective for it. Not many games made me do that, but EYE: Divine Cybermancy did. Not that it was a good shift, nor a bad shift, but it was a shift. Next, there was little room for buyer's remorse from my dislikes. I got it for only $0.99, cheaper than chips (about half as much where I live), so value wise, it is great.

It is unpolished, has an overly complex story with little explanation, and most of the mechanics are left unexplained, but it wasn't BAD. In fact, it was an interesting game, that not only forced me to change the way I saw stories in games, but was a great value at the same time. For $9.99, the shift in perspective is not worth the price, but for $0.99, it very much is.

7/10

reviewText: E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is a defining achievement in the FPS/RPG hybrid genre. Congratulations to the developers at Streum On Studio for turning my indifference toward FPS games into an anticipatory itch for each new mission, city, and world to explore (and survive). This is the game that broke my faith in Metacritic.com (and the first game I just had to write a recommendation for). Its average metascore (60) and rumored learning curve warded me away at first, but the dark and futuristic world shown off in the trailers kept making me curious.\n\nGood thing I gave it a try. E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy has earned more than just a spot on my short list of all-time favorite RPGs. It's also among my all-time favorite fictional universes, which includes books and movies as well as games. Don't just imagine what happens when the FPS and RPG genres have a baby. Imagine what would happen if Bladerunner, Equilibrium, Cyberpunk, Call of Cthulhu, and Warhammer 40,000 shared their DNA.

reviewText: This game is definitely not the best mix of First Person Shooter and Role Playing Game out in this catalogue: The enemy AI is a bit too smart at times, making the game unnecessarily difficult, and you're gonna need to read a very extensive tutorial file in order to get any heads or tails of the interface and its intricacies. But if you manage to get beyond that, you will find a game that is ambitious, but knows what its doing. The story is non-linear, spiritual and at times a bit mindscrewy, with interesting dialogue and intriguing characters which you can't actually read with a mere shallow look, and the gameplay does the job well. If you like bleak, gritty cyberpunk games, give it a try, it will not disappoint you.

reviewText:
This game is highly entertaining, featuring a refreshing cyberpunk environment full of well placed references to many other titles in the genre. E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy provides an unique gameplay and storytelling experience that has me and my friends constantly coming back for more.

That being said, the learning curve in this game is huge. The game will constantly remind you to read the tutorial, do yourself a favor and just read everything as soon as you can. A friend of mine felt that immersing himself in this game was much like preparing for a test, you just need to study up on everything you can. There are many features new players will not understand or use in early playthroughs, but with a bit of patience the content can be very deep and rewarding.

Good Luck and have fun.

reviewText:
Intricate and ridiculous, EYE has earned every wise word spoken for it. It may also subvert every wise word spoken against it, even mine.

EYE is not a success, and it is not always fun. On optimized systems you can expect protracted load times and glaring proofs of the Source engine's age. Much is amateurish; little thought seems to have gone into refreshing whatever was borrowed from Source assets (namely physics and other special effects. In EYE, your hand is the Gravity Gun). And you may be unimpressed by the character models, and sickened by the abrasive sound effects and voices, and the ugliest browns and greens you've ever seen.

You will be tested. Here EYE hints that some of its flaws are not accidental, that they fit into a larger scheme. Perhaps you have played Pathologic, or STALKER, that other difficult game about acronyms. You have a suite of weapons with no clear utility and you will have to work for an hour to figure out which ones are useful. You have all sorts of abilities, but they are also spotty, and finding a way to even use them will take you at least one minute. You begin play with a rough idea that you can improve by spending resources on various things
recommended: some of them abstract representations of the things you can do. You may or may not figure out a plot; you may or may not sort out an efficient way to become better using one of two unexplained single-player game modes
hoursPlayed: or to become functionally better (as in more skilled) using the insane multi-player game mode.\n\nWhen a game puts up one kind of road block
voteText: who would I be to assume its other obstacles are accidental? I would have to be some kind of games journalist. I know that I am no kind of games journalist
helpfulPercent: because all deep questions recede as soon as I do the thing EYE most enthusiastically invites you to do: commit thoughtless virtual murder using a toolkit too large for my IRL kitchen. I blew up a man with a handgun called The Bear Killer today. I then hacked a computer in his friend's brain and compelled his friend to kill their remaining friends. I then summoned three psychic clones of myself to kill the confused survivor. Some mutants came
votesHelpful: and I murdered them
votesTotal: too.\n\nEYE: Divine Cybermancy gives you all of these gifts
votesFunny: but it taxes you. Somehow
commentsCount: this feels thematic: when it is as easy as Hell to disappear a million mutant men with a single shotgun
column16: the real antagonist might be getting *into* it in the first place.\n\nI sense deep genius
column17: and complex fun. EYE makes you compromise for pleasure. When you ask why it might
column18: you see that it wants you to think - but only for as long as it takes to reload."

reviewText:
This game is an interesting one, but it also suffers in some ways.

The general design aesthetic of the game is possibly the most compelling feature. Imagine Warhammer 40,000, but with more of an pseudo-oriental theme. In it; katanas, large suits of armour and mystical powers.

While these are interesting, sadly, the game suffers in gameplay. It is based on Valve's Source engine, and so, like familiar games such as Counter Strike, the shooting system is very good. The guns are all *fairly* unique, and that is all well and good. However, the fighting is very boring. You basically fight waves of highly unintelligent A.I. which more-or-less throw themselves at you for a long time, chewing up your ammunition in a way that feels like it is being put to waste.

I read some other reviews about this game which, to paraphrase, said the game put the player head-first into the deep end. Both in the story, and the class/leveling system, implying, or outright accusing the game of being convoluted and unfriendly to new players. In my opinion, these are nothing but excuses for laziness.

I'll talk about the class system, since I don't feel like regurgitating the story (also, since I haven't finished it). The class system is sort of 'dynamic' in that it assesses the way you have attributed  skill points to your character, and then 'labels' it. You gain experience, and upgrade stats. The game also earns you 'Brozoufs' (money), with which to buy special upgrades. Everything is written down. If you don't know what something does, then you more than likely did not read its description. Moreover, if you still feel as though there is too much confusion, the game includes 20+ tutorial videos, and there exist game guides for stuck players. If, dspite this, you still need to complain about the difficulty of the game, then regrettably, you are only asking to be spoonfed.

The graphics are pretty dated-looking as well (as a result of its being based on Source Engine, no doubt), and this gives the game an 'outdated sci-fi' appearance, and that's sort of unappealing. But you know, it isn't the end of the world.

So, to summarise, the game is quite mediocre in important ways. It is an inexpensive game. If you feel the need to try something mildly original in concept, then I would recommend it, but do not expect something groundbreaking.

reviewText: E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is a defining achievement in the FPS/RPG hybrid genre. Congratulations to the developers at Streum On Studio for turning my indifference toward FPS games into an anticipatory itch for each new mission, city, and world to explore (and survive). This is the game that broke my faith in Metacritic.com (and the first game I just had to write a recommendation for). Its average metascore (60) and rumored learning curve warded me away at first, but the dark and futuristic world shown off in the trailers kept making me curious.\n\nGood thing I gave it a try. E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy has earned more than just a spot on my short list of all-time favorite RPGs. It's also among my all-time favorite fictional universes, which includes books and movies as well as games. Don't just imagine what happens when the FPS and RPG genres have a baby. Imagine what would happen if Bladerunner, Equilibrium, Cyberpunk, Call of Cthulhu, and Warhammer 40,000 shared their DNA.

reviewText:
Positive
+ Akin to games such as System Shock 2, Deus Ex, and other FPS/RPG hybrids, E.Y.E.: Divine Cybermancy allows you to customise your character how you want, with a wide variety of cybernetic implants to choose from, and research to further power yourself up. Combined with solid gunplay (though the enemy AI may tend to idle around quite often and not get behind any sort of cover) makes the gameplay department quite enjoyable for the most part
+ Utilising the Source Engine, the game may not excel in the graphical department, but it does manage to present a well-detailed environment, combining cyberpunk elements and a dark tone; topped off with great physics that complement the gameplay
+ Adding onto the atmosphere, the music is certainly eerie and matches the quality of the visual aesthetic. This is probably one of the best aspects of the game.


Negative
- The biggest negative here is the games interface. Not only does it have a steep learning curve, but the supplied tutorials are lacking and don’t explain all of the necessary elements of the game very well. While I was able to get used to it in the end, there’s no denying that the interface makes it very hard to get immersed into the game due to how unintuitive and clunky it is
- While the level design may be commended for being more open and spacious than the average linear FPS, the size of some of the levels actually ends up hurting the experience. Though I may have never gotten lost, it’s not very exciting travelling through the environments at a slow pace, combined with the fact that there is no real reward or gratification from exploring the empty levels; adding more secrets and hidden side quests would have made exploration much more appealing
- One of the minor complaints of the RPG elements the game has is the fact that you will need to do a lot of grinding if you want to be able to buy/upgrade implants or weapons. You don’t need to upgrade or buy anything to beat the main story, but it’s unfortunate that you are required to grind for hours just to buy weapons that you may want to use, which means you’ll be stuck with the base equipment that you have in your starting armoury unless you go out of your way to grind for better ones
- Lastly, the story is very poorly presented and convoluted; the dialogue especially is a pain to read through (which may unfortunately be due to poor translation). Though the game may have multiple endings, none of them feel complete or give a satisfying conclusion to the overall weak plot. The story barely strings together fully and feels like it’s tacked on rather than integrated well with the gameplay. The game is an okay length at 6 ½ hours (Normal difficulty), but there are only about 11 or so levels to progress through; however, playing the game in co-op could make the experience more fun.


Verdict
“A game marred by some visibly weak elements, E.Y.E.: Divine Cybermancy has both its high and low points. With a bit more polish, this game could’ve been truly amazing, but it sadly falls a little short. Though if you are looking for a good and cheap co-op FPS (and a decent single-player experience), this will certainly entertain you for a few hours.”

7/10 TJBs

reviewText:
EYE is probably my favorite game of all time, but it isn't really a game I'd describe as something one plays for the game's story, or even for the gameplay. One plays EYE for the stories about the game. That being said, the gameplay's pretty good too, if you like Source engine shooters.

I was killed by being hacked by a door I attempted to hack.
The first time I ever fired the Excidium, I got the achievement for killing yourself with the Excidium.
It's possible to make everyone in the hub area hostile to you by jumping on someone's head while there.
I found out the hard way that you can kill yourself by controlling an enemy you've hacked and possessed to a position where it can shoot you.
I've cleared a mission just by carrying a defense turret around in front of me.
It's possible, and easy, to kill the insects and rodents and walrus-creatures scurrying around on the floor, but you'll lose karma.
You can get a PSI power that kills whatever you hit with it, but it also gives you brain damage.
The plural of Brouzouf is Brouzoufs, except when the plural of Brouzouf is Brouzouf.
There's a sword that makes enemies explode. Or does the sword itself explode upon contact with enemies?

Or, the above in condensed form, for EYE veterans:
You gain Brouzouf
You gain Brouzouf
My legs are OK
You gain Brouzouf
Auditive Hallu...
You gain Brouzouf

reviewText:
Once in every generation a game defies classification, no matter how hard you try.
E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is a game you have not played before, it is as unique as it is flawed.

Imagine if you will that you crossed an FPS, a resource strategy game and an RPG and wrapped it into the cyber-fantasy setting.  E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is just that, a unique genre-blend that exceeds expectation in game design while unfortunately failing at presentation (spectacularly).

E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy isn't a pretty game by an stretch of the imagination, its washed out low resolution textures, low polygon count, completely asinine UI, non-existant soundtrack, terrible voice-acting and translation will make many recoil in disgust.

Yet, it succeeds where many other games do not by providing a gameplay experience so unique and well-crafted that all these flaws can be forgiven. The blend of cybernetic warfare, stealth, first-person shooting and resource management provide for untold hours of replayability. Add on top of that multiplayer co-op and the game becomes a fantastic title well worth your time.

There is something incredibly visceral about running into battle, blocking bullets as they impact your swords, landing in a cloud of dust to unleash a power-attack at your helpless foes. Similarly, the same scenario can be played by hiding behind a wall and hacking the one of the troops, taking over his implants and making him shoot his own soldiers. Or perhaps, if you prefer the ranged alternative, unleashing a torrent of projectiles from your minigun while summoning the demons of hell with your psionic powers, warping the frail minds of your opponents as they collapse in their own excrement.
E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy allows for all this, and more.

The haunted atmosphere fits perfectly with its setting and while it might not be the prettiest of games, it certainly is consistent in art-direction. Everything you encounter will be gritty, run down and punk, yet also etheral and dream-like. The world is empty and hollow, and it fits the theme incredibly well. As your body suffers, your mind does as well and you should be prepared to deal with the consequences. Sanity is a rare commodity in this universe.

E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy offers an experience like no other, it is gritty, it is creative, it is unforgiving, and you will love it.

-------
Read more video game news, reviews and editorials at gatheryourparty.com

reviewText:
This game have a very unique atmosphere - very scary and mysterious. By the genre it's an FPS with RPG elements, but the thing I like the most about it - is how atmospheric enviroments and all around you is.

Though this game not the easiest to understand (I still have no idea what's going on with it's plot), but I have to say - I strongly reccomend to at least try and play demo version to see if you like this type of gameplay.

It's scary but without any jumpscares - the whole graphic and sound design is very appealing to me. Visually it borrows heavily from Giger's art for alien environments, and from Blade Runner for city ones - and it works great!

E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is very hard to compare to any other game.

Warframe is apparently heavily inspired by this game

Only Divine Cybermancy doesn't have a $hitty F2P aspect - you buy this game and you get full experience without the need to endlessly grind for resources.

reviewText: Perhaps the most defining thing about this game is the deep story that delves into the psychology of humanity and more importantly, your character, which is apparently stuck in a mental limbo of some sort, trying to free himself while also searching for answers. The dark Hardcore Cyberpunk setting, music and characters all contribute to the overall feeling of the game and combined with the high difficulty, 64 player COOP multiplayer and the intricate RPG system this game is simply one of the best FPSs I've ever seen.. It has bugs, considering it was made by a very small team, and its translation is quite rough (though there are fan patches around that make it much better), but if you can overlook a few common glitches casuals can't take, then this game is a definite buy. TL;DR if you aren't a simple-minded casual and enjoy Hardcore Cyberpunk buy this game right now.\n\nEDIT: IT'S 2 DOLLARS. JUST F*CKING BUY IT RIGHT NOW

reviewText: Уникальная игра! Она позволила взглянуть на киберпанк по другому, прочувствовать его. Признаюсь после темного киберпанка E.Y.E., в другие проекты той же направленности не шибко веришь. Действительно интересный сюжет, которые может отпугнуть на первой половине игры, но развязка первой концовки, заставила приоткрыть рот в изумлении. Но есть еще одна проблема связання с сюжетом, что бы понять всю исторю, вам придется последовательно пройти игру 4 раза!!! Да да, именно 4 раза, не у многих хватит терпения. Графически игра выполнена на движке соурса, не чего уж шибко великолепного, но дизайн локаций отличный. Саундтрек тоже вполне не плохой. Геймплейно игра немного странновата, на каждой локации, в которую мы поподем, практически всегда на нас будут переть толпы врагов, от которых придется постояно отстреливатся выполняя определенные задачи, не каждому такое по вкусу придет. Но есть такие уровни которые просто никогда не забудутся! Один из них - это уровень на военной базе с которой потеряна связь и, черт возьми, его атмосфера просто ложит на лопатки недавний Aliens Colonial Marine. Впринципе игра сугубо на любителя, для людей которые не боятся позновать что то новое. Всем другим, которые любят блокбастеры с крутейшей графикой, казуальщиной и одноклеточным геймплеем, не рекомендую приближатся на растояние пушечного выстрела!

reviewText:
One of the best games I've ever bought.  E.Y.E. is rough around the edges, no doubt, but if you can look beyond its sometimes laggy multiplayer and occasionally sketchy english translations it holds some serious entertainment value, as well as a good story.  Although the storyline is pretty incomprehensible at first (ok, for the first 3 or 4 playthroughs most likely) there is a deeper meaning to it than meets the eye, even after completing all the endings.  The single player gameplay is fairly confusing at first, but there's several guides on the steam community that should help get you set up.  EYE claims to be a mix of RPG and FPS elements, and that it is, with a character creation and leveling system that's not unlike that of an RPG, and solid FPS gameplay on top of that.  The level design as well is very good, and personally I find that EYE has an atmosphere that very few games can pull off successfully.

On the multiplayer end, the game comes with four game modes:  Co-op Campaign, Co-op Missions, Battle Royal, and Team Artifact.  The two Co-op types are pretty straightforward, Campaign is the game's campaign mode with multiple players, and Missions is non-story missions set in the story maps that are fun to run through and good for gaining additional Brouzouf.  Team Artifact is a team-based PVP mode.  The goal of the mode is to take the artifact to the enemy's base, and score a touchdown.  Battle Royal is essentially an elimination PVP mode with random weapons, armor, and health.  Unlike Team Artifact, which plays best with at least 3v3, Battle Royal works well with any amount of players.  The server runs on SRCDS, and setting up a dedicated server if you are so inclined is a cinch, provided you know how to port forward.  Setting up in-game temporary servers is similarly simple, although again port forwarding is required to have your server visible over the internet.

Even if you don't want to pay $10 for EYE at full price, it often goes on steep discounts during steam sales, so if you're patient you can pick it up for $5 or even less.  EYE is well worth the price, and if you can convince a few friends to pick it up along with you, you'll find a great Co-op and PVP experience waiting for you.

reviewText:
eye really like this game.

When you learn how the abilities work and how to use them , there are some awesome stuff you can do , like super jumps and converting objects in the environment to go towards your Health Points.

You can dual wield weapons aswell , which is really awesome.

If you do pick up this game , read a guide or watch a tutorial on Youtube or something.

Oh , you can also play the whole campaign with up to 31 other friends. Yes , 31.

Put some effort into learning about the game and how to play it first.

reviewText: E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is definitely one of the most fun and innovative games I’ve ever played. Set in a futuristic cyber/steampunk world, you play as a member of the secret society called E.Y.E. A special society trained in using psi powers and other high tech gadgets to accomplish their mission.  E.Y.E. is a top notch FPS/RPG game that allows for multiple styles of game play and plenty of character customization. You can go guns blazing, take the stealthy approach or even hack into your enemies and control their every movement. You are also in possession of a huge arsenal that carries machine guns, snipers, mini guns and even grenade launchers. With all these things at your disposal, you know this game has an amazing replay value to it. You can also go co-op with up to 16 players and wreck havoc upon the open world maps. It’s a refreshing and addicting title that I think everyone should pick up.

reviewText:
E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is an interesting game with ambitious features and design but that is also the games ultimate downfall. While looking a little dated on the Source engine it's certainly not ugly. The art style is very consistent and it has a great atmosphere that draws you into this weird cyber world.

The one big problem the game has is the horrible interface and hacking mechanic. Like so many games before it trying to include a hacking mechanic it ultimately fails not because it's bad but because the interface and feedback for the user is horrible. The whole inventory management is a chore that take out the fun of an otherwise good game.

The gunplay is decent and the AI while simple can still surprise you sometimes.

3/5 Kangaroomice

+ Atmospheric Religious Cyberpunk Mashup
+ Complex character development

- Horrible UI
- Awkward controls
- Simple gunplay

reviewText:
Firstly, the concept is amazing. Kind of like a cross between Warhammer 40K (as has been said before), Blade Runner, Dune, Total Recall, Equilibrium, and probably a few other classics I can't think of right now, with a lot of original - and borrowed, stuff on the surface and underneath, including paranormal phenomena, cyberpunk and genetic body mods, hacking, genetic manipulation for basic skill boosts/affinities, and futuristic Rastafarianism. The quintessential Sci-Fi nerd's game, IMO.

There's a money system for investing in physical/cybernetic enhancements and weapons, and research toward the same, all funded by things like bounties, hacking bank computers, and lump-sum mission completion rewards. There's also a skill point-based leveling system with lots of options for specialization, e.g., stealth, brute force, finesse, faster/greater health/recovery, athletics/acrobatics, psychic control/telekinesis, hacking enemy machinery/weapons - even their  brains to do your bidding (but watch out, you may get hacked if they're better than you!), et al.

Some say it tries to do too much. I like all of the things it does too much to agree. Granted, the dialogue seems to be poorly translated, but in a far-flung future, a significant change in vernacular isn't inconceivable. I think it adds depth, in that respect. Maybe it was deliberate. There's also a bit of a learning curve due to a clunky tutorial, but creating a couple of throw-away characters while practicing and figuring out what you like isn't at all uncommon.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is a hard game to review. I love almost everything about this game from the surreal cyberpunk atmosphere to the sick sense of humor expressed through character actions and dialogue.

Unfortunately, it isn't wrong to say this game is incomplete.
It is complete as far as the developers are concerned, but it lacks a proper tutorial system, the game is generally riddled with bugs, the level design can be confusing and sometimes monotonous, and the story is utterly devoid of a conclusion. This game is not for the impatient. You really have to be willing to experiment and explore to thoroughly enjoy this game.

All of that said, if you have the right mindset and a couple of good friends to play with this game can be a blast. The story is deep and is very good overall, but it can be confusing and difficult to follow. The upgrades and leveling system can be very rewarding and the powers and abilities are very useful in certain situations. And if you have enough friends this game supports 32 player coop, so thats pretty fun.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: The game's pretty fun, there are lots of ways you can take out your enemy, by shooting, by hacking, by hitting with melee weapons, by blasting with psi powers, etc.\nDespite what people say, this game isn't stable... it's liable to crashes, sometimes the multiplayer bugs out, the ranking system sticks to the first rank you attain and doesn't upgrade further (besides the Eqillibrium ranks). Some of the achevements don't work. The stealth system isn't much good unless your have a cloak upgrade. Some of the enemies are overpowered. There are fatal wounds which forever affect your stats, which can be pretty annoying (especially for those who are focusing their skill points on single skills to earn ranks).\nOther than all that, it's a fun and challenging game. I highly recommend you play the demo first before buying the full game, just to see what it's like.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Absolutely recommend picking this game up. It's a bit difficult to grasp, but once you get rolling, (and this is all assuming you're a cyberpunk fan) you won't be able to drop it. The eerie and gloomy atmosphere is sure to immerse you completely, the fun, innovative gameplay is bound to keep you constantly searching for new ways to overcome a problem, and if all else fails - the randomly generated missions will always be there for a quick jolt when you're in a race with time.

The story is a marvel the likes of which I haven't seen yet. I read a lot of books, I watch a lot of movies, shows, but E.Y.E.'s incredibly complex, multi-dimensional, multi-layered allegorical presentation of consciousness was genuinely one of the greatest experiences of my life. As a matter of fact - I believe that the specific story (which I leave for you to figure out) is in its optimal medium; no book or song could ever transfer the atmosphere the same way this game does. The amount of thought I put into the thematic of the whole game, and the amount of time I spent trying to understand the underlying philosophical problems - both in the game, and transfered into real life - is unprecedented.

As many agree, if you're one in favor of immersive, drawn-out, atmospheric surrounding, and if you're a fan of the strange, -AND- an enthusiastic problem-solver, this masterpiece will become one of your favorites, too. The game offers too much of the three for anyone to miss them during gameplay, and is sure to have something for everyone who doesn't play video games just for the pure time-wasting aspect of it, but for the artistic value.

And before you decide to opt out, riddle me this - Are you lost? Or have you been lost since the very beginning?""

reviewText:
Deus Ex with JC Denton and the world overdosing on steroids.
Warhammer 40k: A Day in the Life of a Psyker.
Serious Sam: Beyond Serious.

Maps are huge. Backtracking is very common.
You choose your loadout. No prebuilt ones, you choose your armor, weapons and ammunition yourself.
Hack everything. People, terminals, turrets, etc. Take command, convert them to your side, drain their energy or explode them. Yourchoice.
No save slots. The game instead saves after you progress along the campaign, like checkpoints.

This game is crazy in both plot and game mechanics. Get used to the game mechanics and you can little by little begin to understand the plot little by little.

Worth the buy.
Also worth the confusion.

Solid Gameplay, satisfying guns, fully customizable Cybernetic implants that gives depth to each types of character build,which changes the way you play the game, no matter if you want to play it as a normal shooter and focus on combat skills, or go for a stealthy approach, or even focus on hacking skills (yes you can hack your way throught the game! YOU CAN EVEN GET HACKED!)
The whole thing takes place in a neon-cyberpunk/Fantasy setting, crossing Blade Runner, Ghost In the Shell, Deus Ex, with little bit of Warhammer 40K. They nailed the atmosphere perfectly!
Only negative points are the unaccessibility (which might turn you off if you're a casual ♥♥♥♥♥) and the weird-♥♥♥ translation (it's actually so bad it gets good) It's also a bit short BUT it has quite a lot of  replayability AND IT HAS CO-OP and Multiplayer.

You'll both love it and hate it. It's nothing like what you've ever seen before!

reviewText: Alot of people don't know this game exists until a sale. But it is an interesting take of a dystopian future in the source engine with a few more graphical effects and features, such as the armory and weapon dealing. The thing it lacks is probably a map or something to levels  as you mostly feel lost in the cities or canyons. In terms of story, you are, i suppose, a divine knight that utilises the pistols, katanas, miniguns, sniper rifles, assault rifles, grenades, sentry guns/drone and psi powers against the set targets of a mission. You can use skill points from experiance to upgrade the usual stuff, and can even hack into other peoples sentrys and even themselves, to control, or destroy.

reviewText:
E.Y.E is far from perfect. It's weird, obtuse to the point of being frustrating and the dialogue often feels like it's been run through Google translate (Streum On are French, so it probably has). The weirdness is actually one of the things I like about it though. The grammatically flawed text not so much; Streum could definitely benefit from a native English speaker going through all the dialogue and making it less obviously written by someone who isn't.

But the weirdness works. E.Y.E comes across like a blend between 40K's Inquisition and one of the evil megacorps of Syndicate; with it's bizarre mix of psionic techno-magery, cyberpunk gadgetry and John Blanche-esque armour suits. It gets compared a lot to a 'fever dream'; and given the developer's stated enjoyment of H.P Lovecraft, this is not a bad comparison.

E.Y.E's very openended and that can work against it for some - too much choice, especially with little guidance as to how those choices will affect you in the field, can be off-putting. You do have to read around the little windows and you sometimes have to live with a choice that might not have been exactly what you were expecting. Enemy levels can be a tad overwhelming, too. Freely re-spawning legions of mooks are a pain in the ♥♥♥ when combined with big, dark, labyrinths and vague mission briefs and this can make the side-quests (which are pretty basic; essentially retreads of levels you've completed with different random objectives like Kill X, Fetch Y), feel a touch grindy as you mow down two gangs of mooks only to be set on by two more as you reload and scavenge bullets from the corpses.

Steam's recommendation windows are really too small - so, yeah. E.Y.E's interface and tutorials are almost ferociously unfriendly to those of us who've grown accustomed to the hand-holding of more recent RPG / FPS releases. E.Y.E leans more to the school of Here
date: work it out for yourself." Which has been one of the big bones of contention about it for many. Purely for clarity; I mean good
hoursPlayed: not the shoddy modern FPS with the brand name tacked on.\n\nBut it still feels fun; the guns work well and slicing and dicing the enemy with your psionic katana and blue-glowy psi-fist is still satisfying (see also the teleporting into other people to make them explode method). Although it's billed as an FPS/RPG

reviewText: My hacking attempt had failed and so Rimanah stood there with the Black Crow to my head.  As I waited for him to pull the trigger I realised that he wasn't going to.  He wasn't going to because he was waiting for me.  Why?  Because he wasn't there to begin with.  I was holding the Black Crow.  I and I alone.  I lower the gun from my temple and slowly stand.  The wind blows with force now, carrying the stench of half remembered crimes.  I put the Black Crow away and see that my legs are Ok.  So I draw the Damocles and, with a force that sunders the ground beneath my feet, hurl myself a titan's span into the grinning face of the Deuse Ex.  Why?  Because my hacking attempt had failed.  My hacking attempt failed because you can't hack a dream.

reviewText:
a badly translated beautiful & brutally complicated fps

honestly, i love the game, the story isnt so good, but thats not why you're playing Eye

you're playing it to be simultaneously hopelessly confused and yet entranced by deep rpg mechanics that you can actually see take effect in an fps.

the story reminds me a lot of neuromancer/fallout/syndicate, perhaps that is an ignorant observation within the cyberpunk context.

but the game mechanics, the squad based attacks, fighting your characters hopelessness and broken legs. the leveling and sometimes unfair clicky hacking minigame, more than make up for any shortcomings to me.

or maybe, just the fact that the mechanics are so richly done in a genre full of soggy one note AAA games.

reviewText: I bought it a couple of years ago, played for a few minutes, then gave up... I reinstalled it today because I couldn't remember why did I give up playing it before. Now I remember why: the terribly complicated interface and its tiny writings. If you want to understand what's what, what's not and what's going on, you'll have to do a lot of reading, and I have to say, reading those tiny little letters in a greenish/grayish kind of environment involves a lot of eye strain... Now I realize that the name of the game must be a hint as to what you'll be in for, should you decide to play it. Now the gameplay and combat are alright, if you can look past the dated graphics. Overall, its an OK shooter with some RPG elements, unfortnatelly I cannot tell you more because as I said, the interface drives me crazy and I cannot get myself to like the whole thing because of that. For the price it normally sells (on sale today for 1,99), I'd recommend anyone to give it a try, maybe you won't find the same issues I did, and you'll get to have a nice experience. Good luck.

reviewText:
Let me tell that you will have a love-hate relationship with this game while playing it. First of all, it has really a really unclear story and poorly translated dialogue plus the narrative is poorly delivered and mostly received through dialogue.Information in this game is also very poorly delivered as the game's tutorials will teach you chicken ♥♥♥♥.

The A.I  is a mix of super intelligent and incredibly stupid, here's an example; the A.I  is smart enough to detect a dead body and spot you from a mile away but will often run straight towards you and get shot plus they deal alot of damage and this game can be really hard at times [trust me I played DarkSouls] Besides that, the game has alot of glitches and is repetitive in quite a number of aspects throughout gameplay.

Although it lacks content it makes up for really satistfying gunfights, really fun cyber implants and augments, a really nice art style and soundtrack and good character models. Overall the game ends up being just above average I would recommend this game to anyone who can tolerate a little bad medicine..  [actually alot]

My Rating: 6/10

reviewText:
The story of this game can be compared to the Deus Ex series' story, and it's similar in some ways, however the atmosphere has a lot more cyberpunk added to it and it feels a bit more dark than urban and public, like Deus Ex felt. One of the minuses of the story would be that it can be quite confusing, and to get the 'real ending' you need to complete the game 2-3 times or so. It can also be quite unimmersive, and might feel pointless.

The gameplay, and to be precise the combat is rather interesting, and some creativity can be put into the usage of certain combat playstyles. It's quite expansive, maybe not on a grand scale, as it'd be nice if there was a bit bigger weapon diversity, however I do believe that once you get into the habit of using one weapon it's not the easiest to get out of it.

The problem with the gameplay comes with the bugs in the game. If you do the wrong thing at the wrong time, you might end up bugging yourself quite a lot, however I didn't find any big game-breakers. I can, however say that there are bugs indeed, and when buying this game, be prepared to experience some if you play for a few hours.

The multiplayer's alright for a Source Engine game, but just don't expect miracles. It can have issues, and I'd definitely recommend setting up a dedicated server.
Oh also, it's dead.

My rating for E.Ψ.Ǝ. would be somewhere along the lines of
6/10 to 7/10.

I would extremely recommend picking this up on something like a 99 cent sale, or maybe even a 4-pack for a multiplayer experience, which can be quite nice.

reviewText:
Messed up, confusional, mysterious, and a story hard to understand, but easy to match it up by yourself (if you're insane enough). That's why i love this game.
E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is one of the best shooter RPG i have ever played, with a story set in a futuristic cyberpunk world and a plot full of mystery, with a gameplay that gives you great freedom of customization for your character with lots of ways to upgrade your character.

Also being the game set in a distant future, there are surely some features in the game that fits this age, like the hacking system, since everything is computerized (even your mind), that will let you get into particular objectives, control your enemies, rob some money and more.

Another feature of the game is the sanity meter, that is pretty much self-explanatory: you will lose sanity when you see too much strange or bad stuffs, or when your mental power is low, and when you lose too much of it, you'll start seeing and hearing random things.

The game has almost infinite replayability, with  different kind of endings"  and extra missions that you can do for the different map models

reviewText: To say E.Y.E. is an excellent game would be a lie. It's an independant game, and it has it's flaws. The most noticable is it's badly trasnlated English, which makes the already confusing story even harding to initally understand. Aside from that, the other problem is some animation problems, making the characters move around in odd ways. Finally is the various glitches that come up during online play such as saves being corrupted and skipping levels entirely.\n\nPass all of this, comes an expansive world full of exploration and deep lore that with ability to be expanded on even further. The gun play is exremely solid, and while some items are not great choices, most guns are and it makes for interesting and dynamic class specializations. The melee is fair enough, though there is something to be desired when playing a ninja-like monk. The PSI powers are satisfying to use and the way the games handles hacking is challenging but fun. The RPG-like skill points let you specialze  in things like PSI or gunplay or melee and make each new character unique. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of RPGs, it's a unique experience that hasn't been matched by much other games.

reviewText:
A.I. has super situational awareness, but not so super battle prowess. Decent game, has some really cool abilities and tech, along with some interesting weapons. Hardcore gamers only though as absolutly nothing is explained at all, and all of the tech, weapon, magic, etc. trees are highly complex and vague. For those who wish to figure out the best builds by trial and error until the lingo is perfected.

I have read reviews that have said that the game started slow, until you get to a specific point but I found the game to be rather engaging immediately. Suddenly something crazy is going on around you, you have no idea where you are, how you got there, or whether there is actually a there. That answer gets solved fairly quickly but that may be (as of yet) the only one so far.

The only thing that I didn't find the greatest was the, as I said, super situational awareness of the enemy combatants. One bullet, one hostile encounter gone awry and suddenly the entire board knows that you are an enemy and begins to decend (in what seems like almost infinite numbers) upon your position.

The main reason that is a gripe is that the tech skills require a little mini-game to hack" the enemy. It involves a simulated battle between you and the computer program of the target. No shooting here
date: just select commands and the mini-game follows through with a given task. Difficulty is based upon what seems to be toughness
hoursPlayed: of the enemy.\n\nI am a build a charecter game fan

reviewText:
At first, you get a shotgun with 32 shells in its magazine that can make people explode from medium range. That's pretty great.
Also, an SMG that can fire at something like 3000rpm.
And a minigun.
Then you notice you can make clones of yourself to shoot dudes. That's also pretty great, even if they die in one shot.
Then you unlock the ability to telefrag enemies on command.
Then you get a pistol that destroys helicopters in two shots.
Then you get a hammer that destroys them in one hit.
Then you get the ability to just throw a car at the helicopter to destroy it.
All of this while sprinting at 50 miles per hour.
In heavy armor.

it's pretty neat

reviewText:
The story of this game can be compared to the Deus Ex series' story, and it's similar in some ways, however the atmosphere has a lot more cyberpunk added to it and it feels a bit more dark than urban and public, like Deus Ex felt. One of the minuses of the story would be that it can be quite confusing, and to get the 'real ending' you need to complete the game 2-3 times or so. It can also be quite unimmersive, and might feel pointless.

The gameplay, and to be precise the combat is rather interesting, and some creativity can be put into the usage of certain combat playstyles. It's quite expansive, maybe not on a grand scale, as it'd be nice if there was a bit bigger weapon diversity, however I do believe that once you get into the habit of using one weapon it's not the easiest to get out of it.

The problem with the gameplay comes with the bugs in the game. If you do the wrong thing at the wrong time, you might end up bugging yourself quite a lot, however I didn't find any big game-breakers. I can, however say that there are bugs indeed, and when buying this game, be prepared to experience some if you play for a few hours.

The multiplayer's alright for a Source Engine game, but just don't expect miracles. It can have issues, and I'd definitely recommend setting up a dedicated server.
Oh also, it's dead.

My rating for E.Ψ.Ǝ. would be somewhere along the lines of
6/10 to 7/10.

I would extremely recommend picking this up on something like a 99 cent sale, or maybe even a 4-pack for a multiplayer experience, which can be quite nice.

reviewText:
If someone asked me what an unpolished and uncut diamond would look like if it were a game, this game would be the answer.

This game is POTENTIAL INCARNATE. Everything about this game just leaks potential into your brain matter as you play. Definitely not to say this is wasted potential, no, it's just that the game has so much more you could put into it.

The story is vague and confusing, and only in the end you might realize what happened if you were paying attention. It doesn't do a good job of really explaining itself, and I would fault it for that. But at the same time the cryptic story fits in with the rest of the game perfectly.

The game is set in a time where people who are barely human live in a universe that is barely alive, fighting for reasons that you can't quite discern, while being attacked by monsters that aren't quite real, and every time you think you are getting somewhere, you find yourself reliving the nightmare.

If you can get past the difficulty of getting multiplayer co-op to work, you'll find an interesting first person shooter RPG with unique guns and lots of control over how you want to play the game.

reviewText: This game is a fantastic work of gameplay and storytelling. While the engine is old, the translation not-so-awesome, and the rate of research drops absolutely silly, the rest of the game is well worth $10 any day. Zipping around the battlefield with fully upgraded cyberlegs and bashing in heads with hammers and swords has never been so much fun. Be sure to play it again for each of 4 different endings and spend hours with others just trying to understand the full plot. Good gunplay and fun map design round out the experience, all of which is much more fun with more people. Hop onto a server hosting anywhere from 2 to 32 players for a crazy time of monster slaying, federation beating, and brouzouf gathering.\nAt $1, this game is a steal. Grab it and play it. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
This is a game where you play as a psychic-cyborg-warrior-monk thing of a man wielding a katana that's not only powered by some eldritch thing that keeps blinking at you, but can also slice your enemies in half AND block freaking lasers!

You can hack people so that their brains explode!

You can clone yourself and unleash a small squad of yourself on your enemies!

You can run as fast as a Olympic-sprinter and jump twice your own height!

This is a decent description of your character at the start of the tutorial.

AFTER THAT YOUR POWER GROWS!!!



In the name of honesty, there is some bugs and (unintended) weirdness, but if the above sentences didn't grab you then nothing will.

Imagine Deus Ex if it had been made by french people on peyote, while they played WAY too much Warhammer 40K and re watched Blade runner and Ghost in the shell for the hundredth time and you won't be far off!

You'll either love it or hate it, but try the demo at least, if nothing else it's unique.

reviewText: Throw Deus Ex, Warhammer 40K, Silent Hill, Half-Life 2 and a pinch of Heart of Darkness into a French blender, run the result through Google Translate, and boom: you've got yourself some Divine Cybermancy. Even if you end up hating it, it's such a trip that it's worth it just for the experience.

reviewText:
I'm convinced that this game is a golden nugget of genious encrusted in a thick coating of dried, stale (but still warm) feces.

The gunplay is solid. The game mechanisms are pretty indepth for your average shooter. The UI is cluttered as all hell. The setting is trippy. The translation is poor. The art design is full whack.

Overall it gives off a vibe of great potential that's weighed down by questionable level and game design (the challenge mostly being shootan waves and waves of endlessly respawning enemies) and just a general blurry haze of 'what the ♥♥♥♥ is even going on, what am I doing, where am I going, why am I going over there, what the ♥♥♥♥ is that, do I shoot it, yes I do because it's shooting at me, okay now we're here, what did I even just do.'

And it's french!

reviewText:
This might be the most bizarre FPS I ever played. So much, in fact, that reviewing it is a challenge itself. So here goes.

It claims to be an FPS, and yet has a ton of RPG systems, including a DNA combiner with stat rolling. It has melee combat, which includes badass dual-wielding katanas (or dual-wield with guns!) and a ginormous hammer, and yet stealth doesn't work well, as they can spot you from literally a mile away (even when you can't see them yourself!) and you'll be easily overwhelmed by the insane spawn rate in certain areas of the game, with many of them having ranged enemies, and some with absurd amounts of health.

There are amazing (and balanced!) PSI powers in this game, including certain ones that you earn thoughout the game, and can really help you out, and yet you use PSI for almost everything in gameplay that isn't shooting or slicing, such as running, jumping, blocking with melee, and maintenance. Research and medicine are present and very useful (you can even overdose people to death with your syringe!), but good luck finding all the random drops that you need for actual research. Hacking also exists and can be pretty useful, whether to disable turrets or open doors and posess/destroy something or someone, but you may or may not like the system used for it and you definitely need to apply a good amount of skill points to be any good at it.

It has some of the most atmospheric and beautiful places and art style I've ever seen, but also many underused or even plain useless areas. It happens to be one of the most stable games I've played, with only only 1 crash during actual gameplay in my 20+ hours of game time, and yet trying to load certain maps after a few loads will frequently make your game crash, not to mention certain effect like Ultra Violence will make a successful load almost impossible, and the framerate is consistently awful in many places no matter what settings I use.

There's a fascinating story to be found, with multiple paths and even a hidden ending that seems more along the lines of Deus Ex, but first time players might find it extremely confusing until they play through it a first time and start checking out all the logs and getting info from other living beings. You can switch from Light to Heavy classes and use a crazy variety of weapons and gadgets, but not only do you need to level up your stats for dozens of hours in certain cases, you also need the large amount of money to buy them... the hammer is especially insane.

The game has a lot of replayability, as you can come back at any time into the maps and do side missions with random elements applied, special missions (custom maps) or jump online and play Coop or PvP with other players. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to test multiplayer myself since the community is incredibly small, even after the summer sale, which is a real shame.

I'd like to end this review by saying that, unlike what many people are claiming, I actually found this game pretty easy to get into. Yes, the story and the many systems implemented are confusing at first, but starting out in the Campaign and slowly finishing it will make things much clearer for you. There are also many tutorial videos integrated into the game if you need them, and the openness of the map and objectives make you feel more at ease, since you can tackle things the way you want to. Get past those first steps and you'll understand exactly why I enjoy this game so much. It's totally worth it!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An interesting cyberpunk game. For a game that uses Valve's Source Engine, it's pretty neat. You take the form of a cyber warrior that is part of an organization within the shadows.

The gameplay is a FPS, but seems to have some RPG elements with it, too. You can hack enemies to either make them your ally or mess them up. The weapons are swords, axes, hammers, snipers, rifles, turrets, drones, clones, pistols, SMGs, etc. There is alot of varieties of abilites and weapons in this game. Also you level up by killing enemies, so you can raise up your traits. There is a research feature where you investigate a project while you do a mission, the point of that is that it unlocks weapons and abilities.

The story is really difficult to understand since the voice acting is in a different language and the dialogue and text just bores me...

reviewText:
This might be the most bizarre FPS I ever played. So much, in fact, that reviewing it is a challenge itself. So here goes.

It claims to be an FPS, and yet has a ton of RPG systems, including a DNA combiner with stat rolling. It has melee combat, which includes badass dual-wielding katanas (or dual-wield with guns!) and a ginormous hammer, and yet stealth doesn't work well, as they can spot you from literally a mile away (even when you can't see them yourself!) and you'll be easily overwhelmed by the insane spawn rate in certain areas of the game, with many of them having ranged enemies, and some with absurd amounts of health.

There are amazing (and balanced!) PSI powers in this game, including certain ones that you earn thoughout the game, and can really help you out, and yet you use PSI for almost everything in gameplay that isn't shooting or slicing, such as running, jumping, blocking with melee, and maintenance. Research and medicine are present and very useful (you can even overdose people to death with your syringe!), but good luck finding all the random drops that you need for actual research. Hacking also exists and can be pretty useful, whether to disable turrets or open doors and posess/destroy something or someone, but you may or may not like the system used for it and you definitely need to apply a good amount of skill points to be any good at it.

It has some of the most atmospheric and beautiful places and art style I've ever seen, but also many underused or even plain useless areas. It happens to be one of the most stable games I've played, with only only 1 crash during actual gameplay in my 20+ hours of game time, and yet trying to load certain maps after a few loads will frequently make your game crash, not to mention certain effect like Ultra Violence will make a successful load almost impossible, and the framerate is consistently awful in many places no matter what settings I use.

There's a fascinating story to be found, with multiple paths and even a hidden ending that seems more along the lines of Deus Ex, but first time players might find it extremely confusing until they play through it a first time and start checking out all the logs and getting info from other living beings. You can switch from Light to Heavy classes and use a crazy variety of weapons and gadgets, but not only do you need to level up your stats for dozens of hours in certain cases, you also need the large amount of money to buy them... the hammer is especially insane.

The game has a lot of replayability, as you can come back at any time into the maps and do side missions with random elements applied, special missions (custom maps) or jump online and play Coop or PvP with other players. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to test multiplayer myself since the community is incredibly small, even after the summer sale, which is a real shame.

I'd like to end this review by saying that, unlike what many people are claiming, I actually found this game pretty easy to get into. Yes, the story and the many systems implemented are confusing at first, but starting out in the Campaign and slowly finishing it will make things much clearer for you. There are also many tutorial videos integrated into the game if you need them, and the openness of the map and objectives make you feel more at ease, since you can tackle things the way you want to. Get past those first steps and you'll understand exactly why I enjoy this game so much. It's totally worth it!

reviewText:
One of a select few games where the world and lore genuinely interests me. The world combines elements from things like Warhammer 40K, Deus Ex, The Matrix and is... absolutely weird, in the best possible way. The game has a stylish cyberpunk/ religious theme with some stunning level design (levels are huge too), particularly early on. The game is a pretty good shooter, guns feel good and the enormous range of unlocks, stats, researches etc. leaves plenty to be discovered. One of my favourite features is the completely customisable difficulty which includes factors such as enemy hearing radius, sight radius and respawn time. There are a few downsides, the game is pretty obtuse (although some, me included, might like that. There is no hand holding). Also, the game is pretty buggy and I suffer from frequent crashes and derps.

TLDR: The game has problems, but if you like the orignal Deus Ex and enjoy themes from things such as Warhammer 40k, then this game HAS to be experienced.

EDIT: One feature I forgot to mention is the element of persistence and the way your profile levels. It's pretty cool. You can also do secondary missions, which act like challenge maps, if you just want to shoot some enemies, or test new abilities. So far I have spent more time in the secondary missions than in the story missions.

reviewText:
.....this is a difficult one. This game has some serious issues, it has flawed mechanics, unplayable classes, unbalanced weapons as well as a very strange story. But there is something about it that I love.

It has deep music, a very interesting plot. Scary elements as well as mind-screw abound. It also has the darkest techno-future atmosphere that I have ever seen. But it's a pig. Really, it's hard to love and easy to hate.

It is a game where you can go invisible and strike enemies with samurai swords. A game where you will have great difficulty completing on your first run and will be left wondering at the end what to make of it all.

I won't lie it isn't a game for most people, it's very offbeat, very unclassifiable. But underneath all the poor gameplay and bad story-telling, there is something about it I like.

It has atmosphere. It's sombre, dark and sometimes scary. Darkened corridors where beasts could come at you from nowhere if you don't pay attention. Red alert lights flash while you thud your cyberboots around, looking for an access panel to hack to stop the damn defense turrets from targetting you. All while on an alien and completely inhoispitable planet somewhere in a distant future which is calous, cruel or downright ignorant to your plight.

Or closer to home where cyber-punks fight the megacorp soldiers. Chinese writing sprawled in holographic advertisements accross walls. Tenement blocks under siege from monstrous creatures. The spawn of an alien force known as the metastreum. They are relentless, and they never stop coming. But you have a mission to complete, you can let the soldiers and beasts fight amongst themselves. It's the future and it's dark, just like it should be.

That is the atmosphere of the game. But ultimately, it suffers from too many set-backs to make it a good game, or even an average game. Really, it's worth no more than £3. And even then, only if you are a certain kind of person. Check it out on youtube to see what I mean.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Clunky, confusing, with a story that doesn't make any sense (the atrocious english translation doesn't help), plus some occasional bugs in the way...

BUT, if you can overcome the initial shock and confusion the game throws your way, behind all the clunkiness and arcane menus you will find one of the most refreshing, ambitious games released in recent years. This is a cyberpunk inspired FPS with RPG elements that lets you play the way you want to and just have fun.  You can snipe, run and gun, use your PSI forces to teleport directly into an enemy and instantly kill him, hack the cyberbrain of an enemy and turn him to your side, activate your cloaking device, cyberjump behind an enemy and chop his head off with your katana, choose heavy armor, equip a minigun and mown down entire squads in seconds... or any combination of the above. You can do this and much more, playing the way you want.

The campaign is nothing more than a strung together collection of gigantic, cyberpunk inspired, self contained maps, each one with its own atmosphere and style, where you will battle with the enemy AI while completing assigned objectives. The fun comes from the fact that any time you are in your HQ you can choose to replay these maps, completing randomly assigned objectives, to gain experience and money to buy new weapons and upgrades for your character and to kill scores of enemies the way you choose. Enemies respawn every moment, providing non stop action (and targets) at all times, but if you find it too easy or too difficult, aside from the myriad of options to approach the combat the game also lets you tweak the difficulty, respawn parameters and other variables, so that you can tailor the gameplay to your style.

This game is a love or hate affair, but given the amount of playing choices and options and the price tag, I would say give it a shot, maybe you can be as pleasantly surprised as I am.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The gameplay is open-ended, which for a shooter says a lot. You simply get objectives and it's up to you how to go about them. Assassination? Bribes? Brute force? You decide. And the story is a delightful mind♥♥♥♥ that involves drug induced hallucinations and time travel. You begin the game at the end of the game where everyone is already dead and you travel back in time to the beginning.\n\nThis game is a hidden gem destined to be a cult classic, and right now it's a weekend deal going for 50% off. Go check it out.

reviewText:
This is a completely insane, awesome, awe inspiring and beautiful well thought out game. The mechanics are indepth but not buggy. The weapons are fun and a little OP on lower difficulties, but easily able to change the difficulty setting.

The artwork is gorgeous absolutely stunning. I can not recommend ths game more highly. It has a nice mix of RPG/FPS that isn't to far inclinded either way. There is almost a steam punky element to it, it is definetly a co-op game. I've had no problems at all so far, the only real negative i have for it. Is that sometimes it's a bit hard to see during the day, and the load times for joining a LAN is a little bit annoying. If you enjoyed Deus ex/ watch dogs you'll definetely enjoy this. It was a bargain at $1 but for me personally it was a $1 well spent.

The story line is very indepth and can take quite a bit to adjust to but, you can skip a lot of it if you just want to skip straight to the action. You can go all guns blazing but you may die a lot it does cause you to think about how you select your load out for each mission.

And that is the great thing your not stuck with one class you can use all weapons and change if you come across an amoury in the larger maps, they are scattered and easy enough to backtrack and find. There is a steep learning curve but if you keep at it, you certainly get many hours out of it.

reviewText: E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is an... interesting... game. To start out with I can tell it was created from the Half Life 2 engine, the same as Garry's Mod. It technically does not run as HL2.exe, but there are too many similarities in the way it runs, loads, and especially in the options menu and console commands. I would put its graphics on par with HL2, but the story and plot is far below that of the Half Life series. I like the controls, movement , and combat, but there are so many things lacking in the dialogue, story, etc. This game is rough and unpolished in that regard, but it is still fun to play.\n\nYou can choose to fight with a variety of weapons, including a few melee, while using a combination of advanced cybernetic enhancements and psychic powers to boost your abilities. How do you like to fight? Do you like to hang back and control the battle from afar by hacking enemy soldiers via their cybernetics to make them fight for you? Fight with a small squad of Drones to aid you? Snipe opponents from afar? Hack them apart up close? Decimate the area with a minigun? Blast groups apart with a shotgun? Do you prefer to charge into battle, or do you like to sneak around obstacles? Any and all of these things are possible for you to choose from.

reviewText:
This game is not for everyone, it has high learning curve, it doesn't hold your hand, it's confusing at times, infinite AI enemies are challenging (invisible laser snipers are complete BS), death mechanics is unforgiving, but if you look past this E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy will be one of the better games you've ever played.

E.Y.E has a variety of huge levels (Monolith map is one of the scariest locations I've ever played through), awesome weapons, intense gunfights, excellent RPG elements, cool psi powers, sanity meter, crazy movement, atmospheric sountrack and convoluted storyline.

Tips: I usually use B.O.S.C.O sniper rifle (silenced, huge zoom, infrared, accurate, large mag, wall penetration) and 444 Bear Killer Revolver for as a side arm (ridiculous damage, extreme accuracy, huge wall penetration) against humanoid enemies and Depezador pump action shotgun against metastreumonic creatures due to high ammo drum.

Research Medicine first and foremost, it's the most reliable method of healing, far superior to ammo/weapon transmutation. It recharges as long as you hold it in front of you, just don't use it if the charge is below 20 or there is high chance of overdose. Secondary fire to heal yourself and primary for NPCs.

Purchase Cloak augment for invisibility, it will save you a lot of time moving through levels.

Use maintenance to stop bleeding.

Infinite exp/ money (might be patched out): pick two first dialog lines when talking to your mentor in New Eden (2nd level) for 6k exp and 7k-9k brouzouf. Reload the level from Mission tab on character screen. Rinse and repeat. Will get you to level 50 with some patience.

More Karma: kill small critters until you hit red 0 in karma meter. Reload the level (mission tab again) and you should have 100 Karma which will prevent fatal injuries.

Hit Esc and quit the game if you are killed, it will prevent you from using up precious ressurections.

Follow these tips and your legs will be OK. Good luck.

reviewText:
This game is awesome, if you can look over the sometimes quirky and sometimes straight effordless design aspects.

Picture shadowrun without elven stuff or fancy magic, but grim, mind-bending magic.
You basically play a Cyborg-Jedi who gets to throw cars after federal policemen at about 70 Psi levels.

Oh and the multiplayer is crazy, because one guy will try to hack your brain while camping invisible on a rooftop while another guy in heavy armor chases you with a gatling gun so you obviously have to transform another guy's clone into an explosion of gore as you tele-frac into it with the Dragon technique and then you block said guy's anti material sniper bullet with a two hand sword that can also generate an energy explosion on hits.

But as with all games, playing online laggs hard sometimes.

Also regarding the earlier whine about effordless map design,  they obviously didn't have enough time or funds to polish the map Noctis Labyrinth. Someone should make a mod where that specific map doesn't suck. But really.

reviewText: I'm going to preface this review saying that for a game made by 10 people and a half-finished HL2 mod it is a really neat game. It has great combat and story. The XP system has a lot of potential.\nUnfortunately, the save system is BROKEN. BROKEN. It only saves after (some) major missions, so if you save and quit halfway through a mission your XP is in tact but you have to start from the start of the mission the next time you play. Keep in mind that the missions are about and hour and fifteen minutes each. It's a real grind to play. If they had a simple quicksave or manual save the game would be great. Also note that the maps are HUGE for sourcemod. They aren't huge in a good way though. Sprint eats up your power and there is a lot inbetween objectives. Reinforcements sometimes respawn right behind you and score a quick kill, taking away a ressucitator, which take a lot of work to get. It's like I'm playing terrorist hunt on Rainbow Six 3:Raven Shield all over again.

reviewText: E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is an... interesting... game. To start out with I can tell it was created from the Half Life 2 engine, the same as Garry's Mod. It technically does not run as HL2.exe, but there are too many similarities in the way it runs, loads, and especially in the options menu and console commands. I would put its graphics on par with HL2, but the story and plot is far below that of the Half Life series. I like the controls, movement , and combat, but there are so many things lacking in the dialogue, story, etc. This game is rough and unpolished in that regard, but it is still fun to play.\n\nYou can choose to fight with a variety of weapons, including a few melee, while using a combination of advanced cybernetic enhancements and psychic powers to boost your abilities. How do you like to fight? Do you like to hang back and control the battle from afar by hacking enemy soldiers via their cybernetics to make them fight for you? Fight with a small squad of Drones to aid you? Snipe opponents from afar? Hack them apart up close? Decimate the area with a minigun? Blast groups apart with a shotgun? Do you prefer to charge into battle, or do you like to sneak around obstacles? Any and all of these things are possible for you to choose from.

reviewText:
This game is not for everyone, it has high learning curve, it doesn't hold your hand, it's confusing at times, infinite AI enemies are challenging (invisible laser snipers are complete BS), death mechanics is unforgiving, but if you look past this E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy will be one of the better games you've ever played.

E.Y.E has a variety of huge levels (Monolith map is one of the scariest locations I've ever played through), awesome weapons, intense gunfights, excellent RPG elements, cool psi powers, sanity meter, crazy movement, atmospheric sountrack and convoluted storyline.

Tips: I usually use B.O.S.C.O sniper rifle (silenced, huge zoom, infrared, accurate, large mag, wall penetration) and 444 Bear Killer Revolver for as a side arm (ridiculous damage, extreme accuracy, huge wall penetration) against humanoid enemies and Depezador pump action shotgun against metastreumonic creatures due to high ammo drum.

Research Medicine first and foremost, it's the most reliable method of healing, far superior to ammo/weapon transmutation. It recharges as long as you hold it in front of you, just don't use it if the charge is below 20 or there is high chance of overdose. Secondary fire to heal yourself and primary for NPCs.

Purchase Cloak augment for invisibility, it will save you a lot of time moving through levels.

Use maintenance to stop bleeding.

Infinite exp/ money (might be patched out): pick two first dialog lines when talking to your mentor in New Eden (2nd level) for 6k exp and 7k-9k brouzouf. Reload the level from Mission tab on character screen. Rinse and repeat. Will get you to level 50 with some patience.

More Karma: kill small critters until you hit red 0 in karma meter. Reload the level (mission tab again) and you should have 100 Karma which will prevent fatal injuries.

Hit Esc and quit the game if you are killed, it will prevent you from using up precious ressurections.

Follow these tips and your legs will be OK. Good luck.
