reviewText:
-Quick Review-
E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is an indie cyberpunk first person shooter RPG developed by Streum On Studio, you will find many dark themes within this game, and alternative story paths that you can take. E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy was released in 2011 and uses the Source Engine.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  You start Divine Cybermancy by jumping right into the game and you find yourself a part of a complex story of a war between two main factions: Secreta Secretorum and the federation. You're allegance has already been set to help the Secreta Secretorum, however your loyalties are caught between two important figures: Commander Rimanah and your Mentor.
There are a number of secrets and alternative choices you can make throughout the game to different endings, some of which let you chose different factions.

Game Play: Just thinking how do I explain the game play of this game" gives me a headache. That probably should speak volumes for itself. The controls utilize standard FPS controls
date: and then throw in some "Jedi Force Powers". You start the game out with very little explanation about what any of these skills do
recommended: you're expected to figure them out for yourself.\nThere are 3 status bars that you need to watch: health
hoursPlayed: energy
voteText: and ethics. Obviously
helpfulPercent: once you run out of health
votesHelpful: you die. Energy is used for your special abilities (Force Powers). If you run out of the Ethics bar
votesTotal: your character go insane for a little bit
votesFunny: firing uncontrollably and the screen gets really blurry.\nEven after playing through this game
commentsCount: and looking up information on it
column16: I'm still not 100% sure what everything does. Safe to say
column17: the game is a mess... but it was a fun mess to play for a few hours.\n\nAchievements: After 28 hours of gameplay
column18: I have 42/100 achievements. At this point
column19: fellow achiever should be saying "ouch". Most of the achievements are based on RNG (Random Number Generator).\nThere's a whole list of achievements for "kill this type of character". While that might look easy and simple enough
column20: there is a chance table for if the creature you kill was actually that "class". To make matters more difficult only certain creatures can be certain classes.\nThere's also achievements for getting different objectives or quests within the game
column21: different weapons
column22: kills with different weapons
column23: learning new spells/force-moves and other misc. achievements.\nIn other words
column24: if you're hoping to get all the achievements
column25: brace yourself for farming against the RNG-gods.\n\nPrice: E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is priced at $9.99
column26: I personally picked up my copy of the game while it was on a 90% off sale. I recommend others do the same. However
column27: Streum On Studio is an indie company
column28: so they definitely can use the support.\n\nConclusion: Now we come to the conclusion
column30: did you enjoy playing the game?" And the answer is "yes
column31: yes I did." While the game is complicated
column35: and will probably return to it and try to mop up more achievements."

reviewText:
Well, here we are, EYE Divine Cybermancy. This game is confusing. This game is hilarious. There's a lot you can say about this game, and honestly, it's hard to find what to say. And that's a good thing, because if there's so much you want to tell to someone who might play the game that you can't fit it all in a review, then it's definitely a good game. To describe why this game is so good, allow me to abridge my 100+ hours of experience in it into a short story.

As I began the game, I had no idea what I was doing. The story was so convoluted I laughed it off, I had no idea how to regenerate hp, and the menus were almost unitelligible. The entire effect was compounded by the french to english translation, which while not poor, has some funny errors. Nevertheless, I picked up a katana that zaps people so hard they explode and went huntin'.
After playing through the campaign once, hitting level 15 or so, and still feeling completely brainf$&%d, I tried out the multiplayer, joining up with my friend soon gaining a taste for blood in laggy katana combat and hilarious multi kill OHK man portable nuclear launcher shootouts. Sure, the multiplayer wasn't balanced, but that doesn't matter when you're having so much dang fun. Playing even more campaign and missions, I soon began to wonder about the gameworld itself to some extent, learning the names of creatures and weapons. And, while at first blush EYE appeared to be nothing more than a meaningless gibfest of dirty space rasta pirates and future holy space warriors with BIG ZAPPY KATANAS, I suddenly comprehended the extent of this game's universe.
Fast forward to where I am now, #1 ranked active Battle Royale player and almost level 10 in all cyber part stats, and I still don't know everything about this game (and that's not stemming from the fact that I haven't played enough campaign!) Everything in this game has an intrinsic meaning to the complex and psychological storyline, and it seems the more that I figure out about the games protagonist, the more I want to know (and fervently hope for a sequel.)

This game is chock full of anything you could want from a videogame. It's got all the explosive gibs and schlock you might want from something senseless and violent, but at the same time it has a storyline with a depth that rivals some of the most thought provoking games of this generation. For 10 dollas, you can't go wrong.

The world is at first very overwhelming, with quite complex gameplay mechanics and statistics, but gives a character progression that is reminiscent of Morrowind.

If you can get through the sometimes akwardly bad tutorial and hard start, you can look forward to a quite immersive and tactical game.

reviewText:
An interesting game with bad execution due to a low budget and inexperienced developers.

The game feels like a Source mod. (partially because it IS running on the Source engine)

The story itself is interesting, but at times I felt that the character dialogue was written by an amateur or a fan fic writer.

The UI is rather clunky at times and looks bad in some places due to bad usage of text color, text font and overall spacing. Not to mention, the game has received multiple updates and yet a certain bug (UI text not updating often) is not yet fixed.

Some weapon/power sounds feel unsatisfying and the voice acting is weak.
The use of stock Source engine sounds break immersion as well.

The mapping is horrible in certain areas, not to mention that some of the maps perform badly on a considerably high-end PC. (some might say that this is because the engine is outdated or that designing a large scale map in the Source engine is hard, but I beg to differ, as I've seen outstanding maps done in Source mods or by single mappers.)

The weapons are rather out of balance - at the start of the game, you have access to 2 weapons in most categories, and most categories have 1 COMPLETELY superior weapon to the other. Why bother adding 2 weapons if there are no trade-offs at all and you start out with 2 weapons in each category with one of them being completely superior to the other?
Not to mention the SMGs are COMPLETELY inferior to every other weapon in every single way.

The graphics are bad as well. The textures on some objects are low resolution, the bump maps on some weapons are bad and some world textures are not that pleasing for the eye either.
What I did like is the depth based depth of field shader (which I haven't seen in any Valve games) and the holographic sights, but even then, it's something you see in most modern games.

The game's difficulty is strange. The starting mission is easy as pie, yet the moment you get to play the first mission, you get your ♥♥♥♥ wrecked if you're not experienced at FPS games. (luckily that's not the case for me)
This game will NOT hold your hand. It's very brutal and unforgiving. If you're a CoD kiddie, don't expect to like this game.

The RPG elements, on the other hand, are nicely thought through and there are a lot of things to level up and unlock, which is very good.

The gun play is robust and satisfying, although it's really ♥♥♥♥ing annoying to die because of the good ol' Source engine's physics ♥♥♥♥ing up by blocking your movement because you bumped into a prop and got stuck in it while you're getting shot at.

All in all, I'd give this game a 4.5/10. I'd say that this game is a flawed gem, and if it had a bigger budget and more developers, it'd be an amazing game.

Lastly, I have to admit that despite it's flaws I fell in love with this game.

reviewText: The complete and total lack of a real tutorial for this game makes it almost 100% unplayable.  It just throws you in and expects you to get going on your own. And don't even get me started on how dull and boring the beginning of the game is.  No explanation of what is going on or why you are doing what you are doing.  This game is a let down to say the least.  I have not totally given up however.  I will try and play it some more and see if it changes my opinion with a little more time.  But at this point I hightly doubt it will happen.

reviewText: This game goes on sale often, and can be bought for a dollar. Would I buy it for $10? Eh. maybe. The game is entertaining, and even though it says co op, you may end up having a lot of issues with co op.  Me and my friend did, and there are guides all over the web on how to fix it. But with those kind of guides I'm always the kind to mess them up. But, those guides are not by the devs, and they never did anything to fix the issues. So, dont expect to play co op. It ran alright with Hamachi (thats how you spell it right?) but I noticed I was lagging considerably while playing with Hamachi. I dont know if it was my friends connection or mine, although I was the host of the server. His connection wasnt the best at the time, but we havent tried recently. Everything else though, is entertaining, and I think worth the play alone. Although, Im the kind to be playing Borderlands alone.\n\nOverall I recommend it, but if you're looking for a fun co op game, I do not recommend.

reviewText:
Went in expecting Deus Ex, only to find it was more like Dark Souls with guns. Now I like Dark Souls, but at least Dark Souls follows certain rules and conventions. This game is just all over the place. The real 'prepare to die' experience starts here!

-Objectives are often vague, and while venturing around a large map trying to figure out how to get to the waypoint feels like a nice touch of exploration, it's ruined by the respawning enemies (see below).
-Damage is way too high (even on Easy), and a grenade in a tight corridor is effectively a death sentence.
-The fact that enemies respawn means you'll often be attacked from behind just when you thought you'd thoroughly cleared the area. At least you can always run back to the mobile armoury for ammo...
-The grammar and tone of the dialogue feels like it was written by a high-schooler who averaged Ds in English.
-Can't make heads of tails of the plot. The story beginning with an amnesiac protagonist thrown into the middle of a civil war / political coup (is that what's happening?) doesn't make it much easier. I've heard of 'in media res' but this is ridiculous.
-WHY ARE THERE SO MANY ENEMIES, I TURNED THE RESPAWN RATE WAY DOWN, OH GOD THEY'RE ALL OVER ME
-Stats and classes are also a little tricky to figure out. I'm sure they do something, but I don't really feel any different after multiple level-ups.
-Occasional difficulty telling which doors can and can't be interacted with.
-Reloading causes you to waste any unused bullet in the current magazine (WHAT the ACTUAL ♥♥♥♥). Add in the fact that there is no automatic reloading when you run out of bullets and you will choke in almost every single high-pressure situation.
-Some odd level geometry causes problems with movement here and there, particularly when moving in and out of vents or past deceptively small-looking bits of rubble/pipe/what-have-you.

+Saving up for upgrades and equipment is a nice incentive. You get currency bonuses for high-performance combat (headshots, backstabs, etc), so you get rewarded for not just spraying and praying.
+The style of clothing, technology and - in some cases - architecture is pretty cool.
+Some levels contain posters of hot girls with guns.
+The melee weapons all look really cool, and the ability to defend against projectiles makes them HUGELY useful.

+/- what language is everyone speaking and why

Maybe I'm playing this game wrong, but honestly, it just feels bad and unenjoyable to play. 4/10, would not recommend.

reviewText:
It's like an insane over the top Deus Ex, stuffed into a Serious Sam game, heavily inspired by Warhammer 40k, made by people who a) don't speak English and b) are French.

Don't mistake this for merely a pretty jolly game, it's one of the best FPS campaign experiences on Steam. Like Serious Sam, Duke 3D and so on before it, the entire game can be played in coop.

The not very long campaign has a few branch situations, and in general mission objectives are slightly flexible as to which ones you complete and how you go about it, so the game has a whole bunch of replay value. You can play as many playthroughs as you want with your character.

The game isn't afraid of being hard and making you die, and as there's semipermanent (i.e. not easily fixable) death penalties eventually, it also strongly encourages playing well.

Be aware that singleplayer and multiplayer campaign progress are saved separately in your character file, so you cannot start a game on your own and continue with others (unless you start it as a MP game and play alone). One player is the campaign host in multiplayer, this is separate from the actual server host.

(There's also competitive MP nowadays, but I don't think anybody's ever played it.)

reviewText:
why do i always get tricked by developers who go for the cyberpunk style? i'm such a huge sucker for cyberpunk games.

this is one of those tales that never really got translated from french properly, and probably wasn't that good anyway. i think it's an emotion piece, but i don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about any of the dudes in power armor. the only way you can tell plot characters apart is by how fancy or stupid looking their armor is.

oh, and i know that if you really shot another testosterone fuelled 'roid raging power armor friend, they would probably be quite mad, but i doubt they'd instantly turn around and fill you with bullets from their minigun.

what's really irritating, is i mistakenly killed the traitor before he revealed he was a traitor on a subsequent playthrough, and failed. BUT I KNOW I HAVE TO KILL HIM TO FINISH THE LEVEL

it's a quirky game, with some strong points, character and generally feels like a cohesive, yet poorly lit, experience. i wouldn't recommend it though. unless you're obsessed with power armor and mysterious plots that seem to have no engaging aspects, you probably will find this dull and uninspired.

reviewText:
A game that's a mod of half life 2.

It's really rough in a lot of places: The translation and complexity of the lore text is awful, unfinished and generally rushed.

The stats system doesn't have a strong enough impact on the game, I put loads into hacking and it was still challenging instead of easy.

If you don't grind and pick certain upgrades for your class early like cloak or dermal shielding you can get really far into the game without realising you are crippled and it takes a lot more effort to win.

The games ending was rushed and ridiculous with a werewolf throwing out sentences like a child would do to explain whats happened in a hurry.

Lots of large areas in the maps containing nothing at all, except lots of walking.

I can't recommend this game to anyone as it's a rough, unfinished product.

reviewText:
The graphics are immersive somehow even with the 4x4 texture limit generously given by the Source engine.  The storyline is decent, though it's very hard to understand.  The ranged weapons feel good, melee feels meaty, and hacking is partly dynamic on how good you are rather than your stats, which is something I appreciate.

If you have high expectations, don't bother.  This game has many flaws (none of which are gamebreaking), but the concepts are well thought out, if a bit lacking on execution.

The menu is strange at best and there's so many things that I don't even understand, but the research system is neat.  You can also augment yourself very much in a Deus Ex style to boost your abilities.

If you've played Deus Ex or games like it: Yes.
If you can enjoy a game with minor flaws: Yes.
If you use a controller: No.
If you have high expectations: No.
If you're just reading reviews: Play the demo, it'll give you a much better idea of what you're buying.

reviewText:
This game can be boring to start, but once you get to the first city it changes a lot (maybe 15-20min of gameplay), shooting is not so good, and you have to shoot all the time, enemies respawn constantly.

To get the real ending, you have to finish the game two times, that was the only frustrating thing for me.

But there are some features which make this game so unique in cyberpunk genre: abilities, weird hacking process, sophisticated lore and storyline, dark and mysterious atmosphere. There is also some online co-op and pvp which i haven't tried because was too busy with the story.

And all made by independent company.

Enjoyed this game immensely,

reviewText:
This game had so much promise.  Great character customization, with the same equipping mechanism that is used in UFO Defense - want to carry an auto cannon and 2500 rounds?  Yup.  You can do that right off the bat, and you decide where to load it out on your character.  Pistol or sword, light and fast?  Can do that too.

I wanted so badly for this game to be good.  It's not.  Horrible translations.  Rooms literally so big that fog distance applied.  It took literally minutes to walk from an armory to a medical doctor.  I still don't even know what the hell the plot was; even kept asking my co-op player what was going on.  We just didn't know.  The steam engine feels old and outdated.  Hacking is a pain in the ♥♥♥, and the computers were always just better than you, even if you maxed out your skills (let alone the bug where just re-clicking on targets wil *RANDOMLY* re-assign your skill levels, and the targets!

The gameplay is *NOT* what is in the trailers.

1/5

reviewText: I really tried to like this, but it just bored the hell out of me and I couldn't get more than 3 hours or so into it. reviewText:
This is an interesting game to say the least. Lots of RPG mechanics built into an FPS that uses Half Life gun mechanics. The AI slider bars are pretty innacurate since it seems no matter what you set it to they still see/hear you from a mile away.

The multiplayer can be fun but experianced players have an intense advantage over newbies especially if you havent played through the main campaign.

The graphic style is interesting and the storyline is actually unique however a lot of the maps ive seen feel empty. The objective system is pretty nice (I personally enjoyed assassination missions) and allows for open ended gameplay.

Graphics: 6/10
Gameplay: 6/10
Story: 6/10
Replay Value: 3/10

Overall Rating: 4/10

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to play a gun-toting, sword-wielding, cyborg knight with the force caught up in a corporate war?

EYE is not for everyone, but if you've ever wondered what it would be like if in-depth Morrowind-style RPG mechanics got mixed up with Half-Life 2's FPS mechanics, and the whole mix were turned up to eleven, buy this game.

In one mission I got overwhelmed by monsters and my character snapped under the pressure. I had to run like a sissy while my character fired his weapon uncontrollably at shadows and hallucinated explosions.

In another, I accidentally got caught in crossfire between some allies and the enemy forces, and my character freaked out and hallucinated that my allies were the bad guys.

I tried to hack a security console and it hacked me back.

I overused my psionic powers and my head exploded.

---

This game does have issues. If you like to have allies (this game lets you conjure them with sci fi magic), you'll find they get in the way quite often, especially in cramped areas. If you head back into an area outside of that area's mission, you'll find that enemies are set to respawn very frequently, which is not everyone's cup of tea. You can tweak the AI settings and respawn rates in the options menu, but not quite enough for some areas. As many people mention, the English translation in this game is poor, but there's a community-made patch that fixes most of that. Sound quality can be hit and miss, but on the whole the gunplay sounds satisfying. Sadly there is very little voice acting in this game! The bulk of all interaction you'll have with NPCs is done through text.

---

If you're willing to deal with that and you want a game with excellent gunplay, hardcore RPG mechanics, and inventory management, that overwhelms you with options and makes absolutely no apologies for its learning curve and occasionally brutal difficulty, pick this game up. If you're unsure whether this is your cup of tea, I encourage you to at least watch a Let's Play and check out the demo. This game will definitely be sucking up a lot of my time.

6/10 without community grammar patch, 8/10 with.

reviewText:
Overview:
A great cyberpunk RPG. Don't expect to be able to follow the storyline without outside sources as all dialogue in the game is written in some language not yet seen to humankind and risen from the deepest pits of the nine hells. Also, some of it is in French and untranslated.

The Storyline:
EYE's storyline is incomprehensible. None of it makes sense, and it isn't supposed to. There is an underlying storyline that is impossible to notice without venturing into the dark pits of the EYE forums that is only discernible if you manage to understand the dialogue which would require some form of extra-universal 10th dimensional being to assist you. The main storyline revolves around you, a futuristic Cyborg-Templar-Inquisitor. Your character is a member of a Templar-ish space wizard order who recently fractured and now theres also Ninja Space Wizards as well. You mainly fight against 'The Federation' a type of dystopian space government that has no real motives or beliefs behind their actions, and you're never told why you're attacking them. You also combat space-werewolf lizardmen xenomorphs called 'meta-streumonic creatures.'

Most of characters you meet are prone to excessive bouts of mood shifts and are generally mentally unstable. Also you have amnesia, and people get mad when you ask them about things your character should know, but that you donts because its never explained to you. Your character also has a wife, who is mentioned once, but never again, and is never seen. The final boss fight makes no sense and I have no idea why I was even fighting him. Also, there are Space-Jamaican Pirates on Mars.

At the beginning of the game you're told that some captain sent his wife into the forbidden place and she was executed as result. That captain was you. Then you went insane because you basically killed your wife. None of the events in the game actually happen, and your character is actually just living some kind of screwed up nightmare which kind of explains why nothing in the game makes any sense.

10 / 10 would recommend

reviewText:
This game is a hybrid of First Person Shooters and Tabletop RPG's. Like a tabletop, you need a little reading, friends and patience to get the fullest out of this game.

Conceptually, EYE is basically Deus Ex meets the Imperium of Man. You've got some pretty good gun play, mixed with tabletop conventions like having skill points, rolling critical hits and critical misses, and permanent stat reductions for dying in an embarrassing way.  Like Deus Ex, you can run and gun or stealth your way around the environment, but more akin to tabletops you can also hack other enemies and machines to do your bidding or even be a psychic cyber samurai.

As far as I can understand it, the story takes place in a distant far flung future where everything and everyone is computerized to the point where there’s almost no organic madder inside anybody anymore. You work for EYE, a secret agent army working for a mysterious megacorp, fighting against everything from other megacorp armies to the feds (who look like Helghast) to lawless bandits by various means of sabotage, subterfuge and sometimes strait up pop’ in dudes.

The entire game can be played in coop for up to 4 players (It’s actually 32 players, but good luck with that) and should very much be played like that. Think of it like D&D, one wizard venturing forth isn’t all that great and pretty hard, but if you have a party of four with varied strengths and weaknesses, you can overcome your enemies as a team.

The game may seem overly complex and janky at first, but as you learn your way around and excuse the ♥♥♥♥ translation, you’ll have a blast with having cyborg ninja adventures with your friends. Just be careful not to overdose.

Here's a mod for a better translation
Here's a guide on character generation and mechanics

reviewText: Boom. I just turned a Cybernetic Wizard/Samurai/Soccer Player into mulch with my two-handed exploding claymore. His friend wasn't lucky either; possessing him with my superior hacking software, I just had him march into a room full of friends and unload his shotgun. Behaving like some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of Deus Ex, Ghost in the Shell, and Warhammer 40k, E.Y.E is one of the most bizarre and genuinely entertaining FPSes of our time. Research new abilities, mechanically augment your body, learn powerful psychic powers and hack bank teller machines and eldritch abomination's faces, it's all up to you! E.Y.E offers a wide array of playstyles and choices for the player and there's always another method to explore. Feel free to explore the world in your own way and become the biggest, baddest technosamuraihackerpsion the world's ever seen either alone or in co-op with your buddies! Aside from some translation and UI issues, E.Y.E becomes a really fun game once you get used to it (See Deus Ex) and once the ball's rolling you'll find that it's hard to stop. Make sure to look up a few beginner guides if you do buy it, though. Several mechanics are somewhat nebulous and you'll have a much better time if you know what everything does and why you were killed by your medkit.

reviewText:
E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is one of the few games that you absolutely need to experience. The combat is very solid and is fused with RPG elements in an interesting way makes it one of my favorite games to play when I'm tired of other things. You are given the choice of several play styles as well, like focusing on psionic powers, hacking, guns, etc.

Now for the not so good stuff. The story can be rather confusing if you don't do any research into it from the wiki or some other source. After a while this game turns to a grindfest to obtain more levels, money, and research items so you can unlock other equipment. The UI isn't the best either, being rather small and sometimes buggy. Some dialogue that you recieve after completing an objective criticize the player and can be confusing on whether you did it correctly or not. Some enemies are extremely strong early on in the game, so don't count on completing this game in one life. There is more I could probably say, but I can't remember all the details.

This is a great game to play, don't let it's rough appearance convince you otherwise.

reviewText:
THIS IS THE CRAZIEST SOURCEMOD EVER CREATED IN THE HISTORY OF MAN.

Install the improved translation mod before you do anything -at all- with this game. Play as a rambo character and become overpowered first before specializing in hacking or psi powers.

If games were like alcohol, EYE is like a terrible-tasting and mysterious throat-burning whiskey that also makes you hallucinate and you have no idea what is even happening, but it is awful and amazing at the same time. The balance of the game is absolutely horrendous. Stealth, hacking and psionic builds will be hard-pressed to gain any experience, money or leverage at all; If you are not a ghost-in-the-shell holocaust murder agent you are the equivalent of someone with an english major.

The only way to make money or gain experience efficiently is to kill hundreds and hundreds of enemies or speedrun side missions, which could take up to an hour. The maps are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly huge and are designed to be labyrinths. The maps are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥LY XBOX HUGE. It takes maybe 5 minutes to run from point A to point B, where dozens of high-level enemies constantly spawn close to you and make it impossible to catch a break or to heal yourself. Always upgrade your cyber legs.

The AI is actually kind of smart and very vicious; they will throw grenades, rush you, corner you and flank you for any chance they get; when there is a 6-story tall cyberdemon only inches between you and a foot soldier, you are still enemy number one. If you dislike constant long-range combat, modify it such that enemies will only notice you at shorter distances and you'll have an easier time with both stealth and gunplay.

Besides all of that, this game has an overwhelmingly chaotic atmosphere, very well-done dystopian aesthetics, and swarms upon swarms of enemies that present a constant threat and danger throughout the game. The developers crammed so many elements into the game that an invisible rambo super-fast armored gunslinging cyborg ninja who hacks into people's brains, uses psionic powers and jumps 6 feet into the air is UNDERPOWERED.

Cons: Bad translation, incomprehensible to the layman, horrible balance, STUPIDLY GIGANTIC XBOX HUGE MAPS (I cannot stress this enough), no tutorials, a few bullet sponge enemies and a punishing autosave system.

Pros: It will all be worth it if you want your head to explode from all of the chaos. I still have PTSD from the Mars mission. This game leaves me wordless to say what really went on in my mind when every element culminated into blasting down helicopters and cyberdemons the size of grand canyons left and right.

reviewText:
The graphics are immersive somehow even with the 4x4 texture limit generously given by the Source engine.  The storyline is decent, though it's very hard to understand.  The ranged weapons feel good, melee feels meaty, and hacking is partly dynamic on how good you are rather than your stats, which is something I appreciate.

If you have high expectations, don't bother.  This game has many flaws (none of which are gamebreaking), but the concepts are well thought out, if a bit lacking on execution.

The menu is strange at best and there's so many things that I don't even understand, but the research system is neat.  You can also augment yourself very much in a Deus Ex style to boost your abilities.

If you've played Deus Ex or games like it: Yes.
If you can enjoy a game with minor flaws: Yes.
If you use a controller: No.
If you have high expectations: No.
If you're just reading reviews: Play the demo, it'll give you a much better idea of what you're buying.

reviewText:
It's an atmospheric FPS RPG in which you go through missions being a badass augmented ninja, completing objectives, and taking out enemies with an array of weapons, such as pistols, machine guns, shotguns, sniper rifles, or my favorite; melee weapons. How about a sword that explodes enemies on contact eh?

You can buy stuff from the store with money gained from killing enemies, etc, and research misc items that enemies can drop, which can unlock abilities or improve existing attributes of your character.

Hacking is also an element in the game, you can do things like hack a door open, turn a turret to your side, or even hack an ATM! But if you lose a hacking minigame, you will get hacked yourself. When that happens you get quite an annoying overlay on your screen saying HACKED!, and cannot hack anything else unless it either goes away on its own, or you hack yourself to get rid of it. You can even lose a hacking battle against yourself! HACKCEPTION!

It can get frustrating at times, but for the most part its pretty fun, also its a great value for 10 dollars.

reviewText:
Taking roots from classics like Deus Ex and System Shock, E.Y.E manages to become a spiritual successor of sorts through it's eerily similar blend of RPG elements and FPS gameplay. The RPG-like mechanics aren't just a skin-deep stat system though; you will see improvement with each level up as well as access to new skills and equipment. It doesn't end there though, as you will almost constantly be in the process of researching items and technologies that may improve stats, unlock equipment, or allow you to upgrade biological enhancements. These upgrades cover ever part of the body from head to toe, such as increasing weapon accuracy by enhancing your eyesight, your ability to hack and use psychic abilites by altering your brain, or allowing you to run at breakneck speeds and jump ten stories high by cybernetically modifying your legs.

Possibly the greatest thing about E.Y.E is it's unique and fast gameplay, which allows you to play however you want. It's entirely possible to complete the game without ever being spotted by a single enemy due to the large array of skills and items you can use, and you can ever beat the game without ever even coming in direct contact with opposition due to the game's JRPG-style hacking minigame. In the minigame you have the option to attack, raise your defense, raise your attack at the cost of defense, lower your target's attack, or lower your target's defense. This real-time strategy game can make for intense matches against high level AI, resulting in hacking that could last minutes. However it can be said with the exclusion of mandatory events, that you will never need to hack anything at all, which is what really shows that with E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy you can play however you want.

If you want to be a hunter killer that focuses on large enemies and let allies take on fodder, you can. If you want to talk your way through situations and hack a powerful unit to annihilate any opposition, you can. If you want to charge head on with swords and hammers, clearing large squads in seconds, you can. The limits are almost non-existant with E.Y.E which can warrant hours upon hours of gameplay, albeit a fair amount of grinding to gain access to better technology.

(TL;DR)

Overall, E.Y.E is a game you definetly cannot pass up. Although it has it's fair share of flaws and a barebones attempt at teaching the player anything past the complete basics, once you pass that initial learning curve you're on track for one of the most inspired and creative games of the past few years. An excellent gameplay system that incorporates the best of both the first-person shooter and roleplaying worlds, as well as a fresh cyberpunk story with multiple endings and a deep, intriguing history of events make E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy a must play game, especially for it's low (and often discounted) price.

reviewText:

reviewText:
EYE: Divine Cybermancy is what happens when Deus Ex takes up Warhammer 40,000 as a hobby. A brilliantly atmospheric and characterful game, EYE's world is not fine and dandy. From offering to relieve potential business partners of their heads to encouraging a man to commit suicide, you play with the lock on the door between mean and downright vindictive. Of course, the rest of the world is waiting for you to open the door; spirit werewolves, federal soldiers, bandits and giant cyberdemons are amongst the various enemies you can face in this game.

You can use a number of means to go about this game; from straight up rifle combat, heavy weapons use and melee to stealthed sniping, hacking and psychic prowess, there is no singled out method by which one can complete missions. A particular air of revelation is about EYE, making it one of the most enjoyable FPS games I've ever played.

The worst thing that could be said about this game is that the translation from French isn't always coherent. Some of the menus are less than intuitive and there isn't a lot of help moving between interfaces. However, personally I reckon the slightly broken English adds something unfamiliar enough to the game to make it feel more alien a world.

reviewText:
So I hear that some people don't like this game, but I don't really understand why. Most likely they're expecting it to be a different type of game, but it's basically an RPG style mod for an FPS game. That's what it is and what it's supposed to be. In my opinion it's pretty successful at this.

The main problems with the game are relatively minor, like the font size is too small for modern displays and there's no way to increase it. There are some other minor UI type issues that basicaly seem to stem from the fact that it's an FPS engine mod being sold as a game, and from the fact that the game is a bit dated.

The art style in the game is great though. It's basically a combo between the Necromongers from the Riddick movies and the usual cybrpunk stuff (hacking, implants, etc.) The overall level design isn't amazing but it isn't too bad. (It sort of looks like maybe someone designed the levels without too much regard to what quests would be in those levels or how they'd work, then the quest/mission content was added later.) So the levels don't naturally lead you toward quest objectives, but this could be good or bad depening on whether you want your hand held or you want a more realistic experience. (Quest markers exist, but they don't necessarily lead you easily to a waypoint because the actual path you need to take to get there may be kind of convoluted. However there is a spell" that does pathfinding toward the next quest marker.)

In short
date: it's a unique RPG FPS game with a few rough edges in the UI
recommended: and it's kind of dated at this point
hoursPlayed: but it's cetainly worth picking up especially on sale. If you want CS:GO don't buy it
voteText: but if you want a uniqe FPS RPG with a cyberpunk psionic necromonger type theme and don't mind that its an older game then do buy it especially since it's inexpensive."

reviewText:
When you first play this game...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GY7sMsgyuJw

Actual Review:
This game is very fun to play if you can get past all of the problems with the game.

Pros:
Very nice RPG elements, including skill trees, class systems, character generation, and even a very in depth hacking mini game.
Nice gunplay and mostly intelegent AI, including flushing you out, flanking, etc.
Lots of replayability due to the many skills and playstyles, (hacker, stealth, running and gunning, etc.)
Awesome guns and even a sword that makes stuff explode.
Extremely fun multiplayer.
Pretty decent music, (but I mean, I couldn't do better).
Cons:
Really bad translations.
Very bad balance between playstyles.
It is EXTREMELY confusing to start, and for that reason I recommend reading a character generation guide.
I personally think that the pros outweigh the cons, since as long as you can stick with the game it is very fun.
Also blood games looks pretty cool, but I wouldn't know.

reviewText:
So, this is one of those it's a steam sale and it look interesting buys. As it was only a few dollars and it seemed like something new to play that I might start up every now and again for something new. Starting it up the graphics weren't anything to be thrilled with, but if it's a good game you don't have to have HD textrues. Plus, for a game type like this it's not really needed or the most important quality.
Now I want to preface everything in this review with the simple fact that I only played it around an hour of the game.
This game when you first start it up starts to seems like it's one of those games that slips through the cracks and is a hidden gem. Though right after it started to try and teach me how to use some of your basic special abilities I was confused. As what it tells you to click and where to go doesn't always match up with what you need to do. So you just get a view of all of the massive amount of skills/abilites you can have, without having even any solid knowlage of how to use the basic skills. This doesn't even include the charcter creation section where you choose what three gene types you want to splice together with a vage idea of what atruibutes fit your play style. Then when the tutorial promp pops up to have you click the video for what it wants you to do. What it tells you to do isn't the same as what the video is called so you spend a few moments guessing and hopping you click the correct one.
So, once you get past the tutorial and actually start to kill people it doesn't hold your hand on how to get to the objective. Which I actually liked, but there where so many options that it just kinda felt like none of them were fully fleshed out so to say. As if there were too many ideas just thrown together when ended up with something stand alone, but it's so much at once you don't know what you are doing or how some skills work. As well as feeling like everything was half finished before they added on new features and abilites.
There is also the issue that it really likes to lag and glitch from time to time which happens much too frequently to be something that I can just ignore and keep playing. As it got to the point a few times that it just kept me from doing anything.
Also, there are so many menus to go though that it feels more like it was made for a console/controler then a keyboard with the ability to lessen the amount of menus. By menus, I mean menus with in menus. Not just a lot of seperate menues.
Over all, this is a really intresting game and you might like or even love it. Though you will really need to devote time to this game to figure out how everything works, but I couldn't as there were just too much meh feeling about it.

reviewText:
This game is a hybrid of First Person Shooters and Tabletop RPG's. Like a tabletop, you need a little reading, friends and patience to get the fullest out of this game.

Conceptually, EYE is basically Deus Ex meets the Imperium of Man. You've got some pretty good gun play, mixed with tabletop conventions like having skill points, rolling critical hits and critical misses, and permanent stat reductions for dying in an embarrassing way.  Like Deus Ex, you can run and gun or stealth your way around the environment, but more akin to tabletops you can also hack other enemies and machines to do your bidding or even be a psychic cyber samurai.

As far as I can understand it, the story takes place in a distant far flung future where everything and everyone is computerized to the point where there’s almost no organic madder inside anybody anymore. You work for EYE, a secret agent army working for a mysterious megacorp, fighting against everything from other megacorp armies to the feds (who look like Helghast) to lawless bandits by various means of sabotage, subterfuge and sometimes strait up pop’ in dudes.

The entire game can be played in coop for up to 4 players (It’s actually 32 players, but good luck with that) and should very much be played like that. Think of it like D&D, one wizard venturing forth isn’t all that great and pretty hard, but if you have a party of four with varied strengths and weaknesses, you can overcome your enemies as a team.

The game may seem overly complex and janky at first, but as you learn your way around and excuse the ♥♥♥♥ translation, you’ll have a blast with having cyborg ninja adventures with your friends. Just be careful not to overdose.

Here's a mod for a better translation
Here's a guide on character generation and mechanics
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Boom. I just turned a Cybernetic Wizard/Samurai/Soccer Player into mulch with my two-handed exploding claymore. His friend wasn't lucky either; possessing him with my superior hacking software, I just had him march into a room full of friends and unload his shotgun. Behaving like some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of Deus Ex, Ghost in the Shell, and Warhammer 40k, E.Y.E is one of the most bizarre and genuinely entertaining FPSes of our time. Research new abilities, mechanically augment your body, learn powerful psychic powers and hack bank teller machines and eldritch abomination's faces, it's all up to you! E.Y.E offers a wide array of playstyles and choices for the player and there's always another method to explore. Feel free to explore the world in your own way and become the biggest, baddest technosamuraihackerpsion the world's ever seen either alone or in co-op with your buddies! Aside from some translation and UI issues, E.Y.E becomes a really fun game once you get used to it (See Deus Ex) and once the ball's rolling you'll find that it's hard to stop. Make sure to look up a few beginner guides if you do buy it, though. Several mechanics are somewhat nebulous and you'll have a much better time if you know what everything does and why you were killed by your medkit.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is one of the few games that you absolutely need to experience. The combat is very solid and is fused with RPG elements in an interesting way makes it one of my favorite games to play when I'm tired of other things. You are given the choice of several play styles as well, like focusing on psionic powers, hacking, guns, etc.

Now for the not so good stuff. The story can be rather confusing if you don't do any research into it from the wiki or some other source. After a while this game turns to a grindfest to obtain more levels, money, and research items so you can unlock other equipment. The UI isn't the best either, being rather small and sometimes buggy. Some dialogue that you recieve after completing an objective criticize the player and can be confusing on whether you did it correctly or not. Some enemies are extremely strong early on in the game, so don't count on completing this game in one life. There is more I could probably say, but I can't remember all the details.

This is a great game to play, don't let it's rough appearance convince you otherwise.

reviewText:

reviewText:
E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy.
Man, what to say about THIS game.
Is it a Warhammer 40,000 rip-off, or something else entirley?

It is BOTH.
E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is a First Person Shooter/Role Playing Game hybrid, that takes influence from Deus Ex, Warhammer 40,000, System Shock 1&2, Ancient Japanese Samuri lore (I think), and the book Dune.
This is one of those games that comes along once in a while, that shows a REAL depth and attention to lore and universe in a way not seen since Halo, Warhammer 40,000 or Doom, but it too complex and confusing to really catch the E.Y.E. (pun intended) of the average gamer today. It is made at a time when people who mde games for the PC MADE it FOR the PC. As such you should remember 90% of the buttons on the keybord or use 5 different options menus.  So as you can tell, Deus Ex is a big influence on E.Y.E.

You play as an Agent for the secret society E.Y.E. as they try to stop a fight between two rival factions.
To be honest the story was confusing to me, and maybe if I spent more time focused and payed more attention to what's going on, I would of got the story.
Like you REALLY have to be COMPLETELY FOCUSED and IMERSED into the story to make sense of it, and it can be a bit off putting.

The gameplay is like Warhammer 40,000 meets Deus Ex. If you have played System Shock 1&2 and/or Deus Ex, you should know what to expect from this game.


That's all I've got to say about this game.
Play it.
You'll either get a great & enjoyable experiance, or a confusing, unenjoyable one instead.

Broken 3/5

A beutifully ambitious broken masterpiece""
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: An Indie game that runs on Source Engine. I have played this game non-stop for 3 days due to it's amazing gameplay, features and graphics. The storyline is unique in it's own way and has only been done in few other games. I have now completed this twice, and I still have many things to discover and unlock. This game includes roughly 15-18 unique guns, ranging from machine pistols to giant machine guns, along with Psi powers and the ability to hack in to almost any robotic being, and sometimes even your enemies. This game still has a few bugs as it has only just been released, but for a price of £14, I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Edit: 8 hours.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is coming from a person who loves games like Deux Ex, Thief, and from a long time ago, dungeons and dragons. I love complex games, im really not against learning the detailed rules of how to play, but the way a player learns about the game needs to be melded with gameplay, or atleast have an engaging tutorial. Or be segmented, and not have every power under the sun given to the player at the beggining.

If you have to sit through an hour of tutorial videos, where the game explains exactly how its supposed to be played, then it fails. The visuals are dull, the gameplay is micromanagy with too many complicated parts to it, that just obstruct the actual gameplay from feeling fun.

reviewText: E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is not a Deus Ex clone, but it has many similarities.  It's an FPS/RPG with an emphasis on character creation.  It's set in a dark cyberpunk world filled with shadowy organizations and questionable loyalties.  And it is also out of its flipping mind.  It's janky, it's flawed, it's woefully over ambitious, and it's some of the most fun I've had with an FPS/RPG hybrid since replaying STALKER Shadow of Chernobyl.  A work of mad genius?  Perhaps not.  A work of lovably mad enthusiasm?  Most certainly.\n\nRead more here[videogamepotpourri.blogspot.com]

reviewText:
edit: if you think I've totally missed the point, then please comment and tell me what I've missed! I really want to like this game, but I think it misses the mark.

Original:
I haven't got the remotest ****ing clue what is going on in this game. And not in a clever, mysterious, well-crafted-world-where-not-all-is-as-it-seems way, which it's clear the devs were trying for. Even overlooking the english-as-a-second-language mistakes, the writing is utter garbage. Too many factions and characters introduced too quickly and making no apparent difference to what's going on.

I have amnesia and don't know anything about my situation, yet I have opinions and memories about various characters?

More importantly, I don't understand the gameplay mechanics and there's very little explanation. You need to remember the briefing dialogue, because despite there being a high tech character UI it doesn't record dialogue and the objectives it does record don't give you any idea why you're doing them if you don't remember the details.


This game is a mess. It wants very badly to be a blend of Syndicate, Deus Ex, and possibly Fallout's Brotherhood of Steel. It doesn't succeed. There's probably a good game somewhere in there, but there's so much mess that should have been stripped out or implemented better.

Not explaining anything in game is not a substitute for cleverness. It's just an inscrutable, badly put together mess.
voteText: 19 of 39 people (49%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: A surfeit of good ideas undone by ♥♥♥♥ poor execution.  I can't think of another game which is, by turns, as awesome and awful as E.Y.E.  It creates a great first impression, however, with one of the biggest and (seemingly) complex stat and upgrade systems of any action RPG out there, with lots of different unique powers to buy (invisibility cloaks, the ability to clone yourself and control enemies with your mind, etc, etc) and scores of different weapons (most of which handle pretty well).\n\nUnfortunately, all of these good ideas can't do much to counter the game's terrible A.I., boring combat, constantly respawning enemies, erratic level design (some are well done, while others are just big empty boxes), and incomprehensible writing/storyline.  So at the end of the day the game's RPG pretensions are for naught: no matter how many upgrades you buy or how many times you level up the game still plays like an amateurish, unfinished, sub-mediocre Half-Life 2 mod.

reviewText:
As others have said, it's near impossible to know what is going on due to bad translations and seemingly a lack of good organization, therefore it is difficult to maintain interest in the plot...whatever that is. The dialogue reads like a child whose second language is English wrote it; overly simple and full of mistakes. This GREATLY affects immersion. Immersion is kind of important in a story-driven/RPG game.

Speaking of the dialogue, it's text-based and a ton of reading. If I wanted to read a badly written story, I'd pick up a book by whoever wrote 'Twilight'. Despite that, the premise is good from what I read on the store page; it may not have been half as bad if the translation were better and the dialogue less childlike.

The graphics are good but devoid of anything interesting or much that's interactive, there is a lot of empty space to trudge through.

UI and UX are an absolute mess. If you want to play with a controller, forget about it. You won't be able to access most anything via controller besides cycling through weapons, using the weapons, and pausing the game. Though you can control movement with a controller... Everything else (picking things up, hacking, dialogue, accessing UI, etc.) must be done with the keyboard, so it's simpler to stick with the keyboard/mouse combo throughout. I feel there is way too much going on with the various menus, it was not intuitive whatsoever and took too long for me to grow accustomed to.

0/10 -- I found no redeeming qualities, even the low price I paid. In an RPG I want to INTERACT, be a PART of and guide the story. None of those things were possible for me here. I don't hate this game, I simply find nothing to recommend it.

1/11: edited to include more info re: gamepad vs. keyboard/mouse

reviewText:
Warning: This Game is not Controller Friendly.

This may not be an issue for a lot of people, but it was an absolute deal breaker for me.  Normally, when a game is listed as having Partial Controller Support, it is mostly playable with your controller and only occasionally requires you to use your mouse or keyboard.  This is simply not the case with this game.  There are far too many required functions to be able to map them all to a standard controller, so you will need to use your keyboard so much that even attempting to use the controller just seems pointless.

Again, I realize that this isn't  an issue for a lot of PC gamers, but I feel like those who, like me, prefer to play their games wilth a controller will be disappointed with just how hard it is to play this game with one.  It's too bad; this one looks like it could have been a fun cyberpunk adventure.

reviewText: This is the kind of game that I want to like, but end up hating in the end. The game has a great art style, decent sound design, and decent graphics, everything else is pretty much a mess. The game explains itself very poorly and has a cluttered UI that makes getting into the game a pain. Random things seem to happen with seemingly no explanation such as going insane, losing karma, killing yourself, and so on. The combat is fairly clunky as well, with enemies who have vision that covers almost the entire map which makes stealth nearly impossible, along with the fact that enemies will spawn infinitely after one has been alerted leading to endless shootouts that keep you from getting to your objective in a timely manner. On top of that item management is a pain, you have to go into an inventory menu, toss out your weapon, then walk over to the weapon you want to pick up in order to pick up a new weapon, and managing your ammunition requires using that same time-consuming menu. On top of that the game punishes you for things like using a healing stim and forces you to go insane (Literally). Beyond that the controls are mediocre at best with having to use the enter button for things like picking up ammo or climbing ladders, even leaning has a massive delay and sometimes simply doesn't work. The game itself is rather tedious with most missions simply being go from point A to point B while trying not to get killed by the army of goons inbetween. If you've got the money to spare and absolutely nothing better to do, go ahead and buy it, but it's not an easy game to get into, and you'll have to look past a lot of bad aspects in order to enjoy it.

reviewText:
Bad things first:
Awful, just awful level design. I would expect something like this when i was playing 15 year old games. Levels are huge and empty and just feel confusing as someone with multiple personality disorder would design.

Level design is not the only thing that is 15 years old - user interface is also something out of 90's. To open an inventory, you have to hold down C, drag mouse down, let go of C, select inventory from full screen of text and other stuff. There wasnt a way to bind a key to the inventory. Why would you design it like this?

Respawning enemies. What were they thinking? I am just curious how the playtesting was, because this makes you constantly out of ammo and makes the stealth almost useless. Aside from the fact that AI's basically have unlimited sight nor does the level design support the stealth.

Things that are good:
Text is good. It is well written. I enjoyed reading the background lore, but when you are not reading, the levels jump from one location to another and you have no idea what's going on.

Conclusion: 15 years behind in level design, UI design and gameplay design. That's a sunken boat that even interesting text could not save. I do not recommend this game. Only buy this if it is on sale and try the demo before you buy.

PS: I am probably a minority expressing this opinion of this game. If you like this game then we don't have the same taste in games.

reviewText:
I've tried to like EYE, I really wanted to like EYE. I waited for the game to be patched, I've tried the fan text revamp. But in the end the entire game is just so obtuse, esoteric, and poorly put together it just all falls apart.

The levels are often far too large for what is in them (the hub level is this to the extreme), and and the lack of a map and any clear indicators as to what is intercative or not adds more confusion along with the poor lighting. The enemy spawn system is a nightmare and the gunplay is ok at best. The plot is also a gibbering mess that would give Stanley Kubrick a headache.

In the end I'd give it a 3.5/10

reviewText: Straight to it: the save function is quirkly designed and unexpected. The gameplay itself is rather clunky, too. I've no interest in playing a RPG that doesn't allow me to save my progress whenever I want, or that has checkpoint saves so far apart that it literally would take hours to reach each one if you chose to opt for sidequests. For that matter, I've little time to play anything built on the Source engine. It's decrepit; the graphics feel like late '90's, and player interactions with the environment feel decidedly antiquated.  Finally, why is the game so dark? It's really freaking dark! In the same vein as Doom 3.\n\nTL;DR: Bad save system by design and old engine leaves this one for the hardcore nerds who have LOTS of time to blow off.

reviewText:
It feels more like a very ambitious Half Life mod than a full fledged game.
Maybe it gets cooler if you put some hours into it, but so far its a very mediocre shooter with clumsily glued-on elements like Hacking and Stealth.

I dont mind an amateurish tutorial that informs you from time to time that you should now look up a minimalistic video from another menu.
Same thing with the sad AI. Smarter is not automatically better (although the game makes modern FPS bots look like Turing-Test-beating quantum-machines).
The terrible pacing- my inner cyborg can still cope. Lots of games have terrible pacing these days.
Even E.Y.E.'s  inability to communicate even an excuse of a story is not the final nail in the coffin.

What REALLY kills the mood is the terrible art direction.
I signed in for some Cyberpunk gawddammit- this is just a mess!
Think late 90s FPS:
Barely recognizable enemies amidst giant, barrel-filled halls that follow no sensible design or function.

The reviewborg shed 1,5/ 5 tears ....in ... rain

reviewText: There's very little hook to get you interested in the story, and what little story this title presents is crumbling under the weight of an incompetent or simply nonexistent editor. Don't expect to be emotionally invested in this game, because both the story and the mechanics are both so poorly presented as to be incomprehensible. There might be a really great experience hidden somewhere beneath the broken tutorial system, the completely uninteresting characters, and the mediocre environment design, but this strictly amateur work is turning me off from digging any deeper to try and find it. Forget about polishing" this
date: what this title needs is to have the finish stripped
hoursPlayed: and to have the entire user experience reworked from the bare metal.\n\nYou can tell that a lot of work has been put into the foundational elements of the gameplay - the damage/HP/healing system
voteText: the level-up system
helpfulPercent: the different abilities and weapons
votesHelpful: and even the hacking mechanic - but it's all presented in a bland way that makes me think the team got bored with making this game halfway through and decided to phone it in as soon as the levels were designed and the largest bugs in the gameplay were ironed out. It feels like an "Early Access" title that never made it to version 1.0."
